article:
UFC 273: Volkanovski vs. The Korean Zombie was a mixed martial arts event produced by the Ultimate Fighting Championship that took place on April 9, 2022, at the VyStar Veterans Memorial Arena in Jacksonville, Florida.

# Background

UFC 273 was the first event held by the organization in Jacksonville since UFC 261 in April 2021. The event was originally scheduled to take place on April 16, 2022, but was later rescheduled for April 9, 2022.

The event was headlined by a featherweight title fight between current champion Alexander Volkanovski and former title challenger Chan Sung Jung, also known as The Korean Zombie. The two fighters were originally scheduled to face each other at UFC 273, but the fight was later canceled due to Volkanovski's withdrawal from the event. However, the fight was rebooked for UFC 273 after Volkanovski recovered from his injury.

In addition to the featherweight title fight, the event also featured a bantamweight title fight between current champion Aljamain Sterling and former champion Petr Yan. The two fighters have a long history of tension, dating back to their first fight at UFC 259 in March 2021. Yan was originally scheduled to face Sterling for the title at UFC 267 in October 2021, but was forced to withdraw from the event due to a neck injury.

## Notable suspensions

Several fighters on the UFC 273 card received medical suspensions following the event. The most notable suspension was given to Chan Sung Jung, who was suspended for 180 days due to a right orbital fracture. Other fighters who received medical suspensions included Aljamain Sterling (45 days), Petr Yan (30 days), and Aspen Ladd (30 days).

# Results

## Preliminary card

* Women's Bantamweight: Julija Stoliarenko defeated Julia Avila via submission (armbar) at 0:42 of round 1.
* Flyweight: Anthony Hernandez defeated Josh Fremd via unanimous decision (30-27, 30-27, 30-27).
* Bantamweight: Chris Duncan defeated Michal Figlak via unanimous decision (29-28, 29-28, 29-28).
* Welterweight: Mark Madsen defeated Vinc Pichel via unanimous decision (29-28, 29-28, 29-28).
* Women's Strawweight: Piera Rodriguez defeated Kay Hansen via unanimous decision (29-28, 29-28, 29-28).
* Middleweight: Khamzhat Chimaev defeated Gilbert Burns via unanimous decision (29-28, 29-28, 29-28).

## Main card

* Featherweight: Alexander Volkanovski defeated Chan Sung Jung via TKO (punches) at 0:45 of round 4.
* Bantamweight: Aljamain Sterling defeated Petr Yan via split decision (47-48, 48-47, 48-47).
* Women's Bantamweight: Raquel Pennington defeated Aspen Ladd via unanimous decision (29-28, 29-28, 29-28).
* Middleweight: Khamzhat Chimaev defeated Gilbert Burns via unanimous decision (29-28, 29-28, 29-28).

# Bonus awards

The following fighters received bonus awards:

* Fight of the Night: Aljamain Sterling vs. Petr Yan
* Performance of the Night: Alexander Volkanovski

# See also

* List of UFC events
* List of current UFC fighters
* Ultimate Fighting Championship

article:
The Undertaker

Mark William Calaway, better known by his ring name The Undertaker, is a retired American professional wrestler. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest professional wrestlers of all time. With a career spanning over three decades, The Undertaker has established himself as a legendary figure in the world of sports entertainment.

#Early life

Mark Calaway was born on March 24, 1965, in Houston, Texas. He grew up in a family of modest means and was raised by his parents, Frank and Catherine Calaway. Calaway's early life was marked by a strong interest in sports, particularly basketball and football. He attended Waltrip High School in Houston, where he played football and basketball. After graduating from high school, Calaway attended Texas Wesleyan University, where he played basketball on a scholarship. However, he dropped out of college after one year to pursue a career in professional wrestling.

#Professional wrestling career

##Early career (1987–1989)

Calaway began his professional wrestling career in 1987, working for various independent promotions in the United States. He adopted the ring name "Texas Red" and worked for the World Class Championship Wrestling (WCCW) promotion in Texas. During this time, Calaway honed his skills and developed his in-ring style.

##World Championship Wrestling (1989–1990)

In 1989, Calaway joined World Championship Wrestling (WCW), where he adopted the ring name "Mean Mark Callous." He worked as a heel (villain) and feuded with various wrestlers, including Ricky Steamboat and Eddie Gilbert. Calaway's time in WCW was marked by a series of forgettable feuds and mediocre matches.

##World Wrestling Federation/Entertainment/WWE

###Debut of The Undertaker (1990–1991)

In 1990, Calaway joined the World Wrestling Federation (WWF), which later became World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE). He adopted the ring name "The Undertaker" and made his debut at the 1990 Survivor Series. The Undertaker was introduced as a mysterious and intimidating figure, with a deadman gimmick that captivated audiences.

###WWF Champion and beginning of The Streak (1991–1994)

In 1991, The Undertaker won his first WWF Championship, defeating Hulk Hogan at Survivor Series. He held the title for several months, feuding with various wrestlers, including Hogan and Ric Flair. During this time, The Undertaker began to establish his undefeated streak at WrestleMania, which would become a hallmark of his career.

###Rebirthed Deadman (1994–1996)

In 1994, The Undertaker underwent a transformation, adopting a more supernatural and mystical persona. He feuded with Yokozuna and Kamala, and established himself as a dominant force in the WWF.

###Lord of Darkness (1996–1998)

In 1996, The Undertaker became the "Lord of Darkness," a darker and more ominous persona. He feuded with Mankind and Shawn Michaels, and established himself as one of the top stars in the WWF.

###Ministry of Darkness Deadman (1998–1999)

In 1998, The Undertaker formed the Ministry of Darkness, a stable of wrestlers that included Faarooq, Bradshaw, and Mankind. He feuded with Stone Cold Steve Austin and The Rock, and established himself as a dominant force in the WWF.

###American Badass (2000–2001)

In 2000, The Undertaker underwent a transformation, adopting a more laid-back and rebellious persona. He feuded with Triple H and Steve Austin, and established himself as a top star in the WWF.

###Big Evil (2001–2003)

In 2001, The Undertaker became "Big Evil," a more aggressive and dominant persona. He feuded with Kurt Angle and Brock Lesnar, and established himself as one of the top stars in the WWF.

###Return of the Deadman (2004–2007)

In 2004, The Undertaker returned to his deadman gimmick, feuding with Randy Orton and Rey Mysterio. He established himself as a dominant force in the WWE, and continued to build his undefeated streak at WrestleMania.

###World Heavyweight Champion (2007–2010)

In 2007, The Undertaker won the World Heavyweight Championship, defeating Batista at WrestleMania 23. He held the title for several months, feuding with Edge and CM Punk.

###Final years of The Streak (2011–2014)

In 2011, The Undertaker continued to build his undefeated streak at WrestleMania, defeating Triple H at WrestleMania 27. He feuded with CM Punk and Brock Lesnar, and established himself as a dominant force in the WWE.

###Final feuds (2015–2020)

In 2015, The Undertaker feuded with Bray Wyatt and Brock Lesnar, establishing himself as a dominant force in the WWE. He continued to compete sporadically, feuding with Roman Reigns and Shane McMahon.

###Retirement and Hall of Fame (2020–2022)

In 2020, The Undertaker announced his retirement from professional wrestling. He was inducted into the WWE Hall of Fame in 2022, a testament to his enduring legacy in the world of sports entertainment.

###Sporadic appearances (2023–present)

In 2023, The Undertaker made sporadic appearances for the WWE, including a appearance at WrestleMania 39. He continues to be involved in the WWE, albeit in a limited capacity.

#Undertaker gimmick, identities and character evolution

##The Deadman identity

The Undertaker's deadman gimmick is one of the most iconic and enduring personas in professional wrestling. It is characterized by a slow and deliberate in-ring style, as well as a series of supernatural and mystical themes.

##Alternate identities of The Undertaker gimmick

The Undertaker has adopted several alternate identities throughout his career, including the "American Badass" and "Big Evil" personas. These personas have been marked by a more aggressive and dominant in-ring style.

##Gimmick reflective nicknames

The Undertaker has been known by several nicknames throughout his career, including "The Deadman" and "The Phenom." These nicknames reflect his deadman gimmick and his reputation as a dominant force in the WWE.

##Domestic backstory, parents and brother

The Undertaker's domestic backstory is marked by a complex and troubled relationship with his parents and brother. This backstory has been explored in various storylines throughout his career.

##Gimmick fused with wrestling move set and style

The Undertaker's gimmick is closely tied to his in-ring style, which is characterized by a slow and deliberate approach. His move set is marked by a series of powerful and dominating moves, including the Tombstone Piledriver.

##Calaway's performance of The Deadman

Mark Calaway's performance of The Undertaker is widely regarded as one of the greatest in professional wrestling. He has brought the character to life through his in-ring style, as well as his various personas and storylines.

#Legacy and reception

##Recognitions and acclaim

The Undertaker has been recognized as one of the greatest professional wrestlers of all time. He has been inducted into the WWE Hall of Fame and has won numerous awards and accolades throughout his career.

##Reception to later career

The Undertaker's later career has been marked by a series of critically acclaimed performances. He has continued to evolve and adapt, establishing himself as a dominant force in the WWE.

#Personal life

Mark Calaway is married to Michelle McCool, a former WWE wrestler. He has two daughters, Chasey and Gracie. Calaway is a private person and keeps his personal life out of the spotlight.

#Appearances and references in external media forums

##Big screen and small screen roles

The Undertaker has made appearances in various films and television shows, including "Suburban Commando" and "Beyond the Mat."

#Video games

The Undertaker has appeared in numerous video games, including the WWE 2K series and WWE All Stars.

#Championships and accomplishments

* WWE Champion (7 times)
* World Heavyweight Champion (3 times)
* WWF Tag Team Champion (6 times)
* WWF Hardcore Champion (1 time)
* Royal Rumble winner (2007)
* Survivor Series winner (1996, 2007)

#Other awards and honors

* WWE Hall of Fame (2022)
* Wrestling Observer Newsletter Hall of Fame (2004)
* Pro Wrestling Illustrated Wrestler of the Year (1997, 1998)

#WrestleMania record

The Undertaker has an undefeated streak at WrestleMania, with a record of 25-0.

#Luchas de Apuestas record

The Undertaker has a record of 4-0 in Luchas de Apuestas matches.

#Notes

The Undertaker's legacy continues to be felt in the world of sports entertainment. He remains one of the most iconic and enduring figures in professional wrestling.

article:
Prosecution of Donald Trump in New York

The prosecution of Donald Trump in New York refers to the criminal case against the 45th President of the United States, Donald Trump, in the state of New York. The case, which is being prosecuted by the Manhattan District Attorney's Office, centers on allegations of falsifying business records and other financial crimes related to Trump's dealings with adult film actress Stormy Daniels.

# Background

## Stormy Daniels–Donald Trump scandal

In 2006, Donald Trump allegedly had an affair with adult film actress Stormy Daniels, whose real name is Stephanie Clifford. Trump denied the affair, but in 2016, just before the presidential election, Daniels was paid $130,000 by Trump's personal attorney, Michael Cohen, to keep quiet about the alleged affair. This payment was made through a shell company called Essential Consultants, LLC, which was established by Cohen for this purpose.

## Manhattan DA investigation and grand jury

In 2019, the Manhattan District Attorney's Office (DANY) launched an investigation into Trump's dealings with Daniels and the payment made to her. The investigation was led by District Attorney Cyrus Vance Jr. and focused on potential crimes such as falsifying business records and violating campaign finance laws.

In August 2022, a grand jury was convened to hear evidence in the case. The grand jury was tasked with determining whether there was enough evidence to indict Trump on charges related to the payment to Daniels.

## Eligibility for president

Some have questioned whether a conviction in this case would affect Trump's eligibility to run for president again in the future. However, most experts agree that a state-level conviction would not automatically disqualify Trump from running for federal office.

# Initial proceedings

## Indictment and charges

On March 30, 2023, Trump was indicted by the grand jury on charges of falsifying business records in the first degree, a Class E felony. The indictment alleged that Trump had directed Michael Cohen to make the payment to Daniels and then falsely recorded the payment as a legal expense in his company's books.

## Arraignment

Trump was arraigned on April 4, 2023, and pleaded not guilty to the charges. He was released on his own recognizance and ordered to return to court for a pre-trial conference.

# Pre-trial proceedings

## Request for indictment dismissal

In April 2023, Trump's lawyers filed a motion to dismiss the indictment, arguing that the charges were politically motivated and that the prosecution had presented insufficient evidence to the grand jury. The motion was denied by the court.

## Discovery materials and witnesses

In May 2023, the prosecution turned over discovery materials to Trump's lawyers, including documents and witness statements related to the case. The materials included testimony from several key witnesses, including Michael Cohen and Stormy Daniels.

## Requests for recusal

In June 2023, Trump's lawyers filed a motion to recuse the judge presiding over the case, arguing that he had made biased comments about Trump in the past. The motion was denied by the court.

## Request for removal to federal court

In July 2023, Trump's lawyers filed a motion to remove the case to federal court, arguing that the charges were related to federal campaign finance laws. The motion was denied by the court.

## Trial scheduling

In August 2023, the court scheduled the trial to begin on October 2, 2023.

## Gag order

In September 2023, the court issued a gag order, prohibiting Trump and his lawyers from making public statements about the case.

## Statute of limitations

Some have questioned whether the statute of limitations has expired on the charges against Trump. However, the prosecution has argued that the statute of limitations was tolled due to Trump's alleged concealment of the crime.

# Overview of witnesses

The prosecution is expected to call several key witnesses in the case, including:

* Michael Cohen
* Stormy Daniels
* Keith Davidson, a lawyer who represented Daniels in her negotiations with Trump
* Hope Hicks, a former Trump aide
* David Pecker, the CEO of American Media, Inc., which published the National Enquirer

# Trial

## Jury selection and opening statements

The trial began on October 2, 2023, with jury selection. The prosecution and defense delivered opening statements to the jury.

## Contempt hearings

During the trial, Trump's lawyers were held in contempt of court for violating the gag order.

## Prosecution witnesses

### David Pecker

David Pecker testified about his company's involvement in the payment to Daniels and the publication of a story about Trump's alleged affair with Daniels.

### Graff, Farro, Browning, and Thompson

Several executives from American Media, Inc. testified about the company's role in the payment to Daniels.

### Keith Davidson and Douglas Daus

Keith Davidson and Douglas Daus, lawyers who represented Daniels in her negotiations with Trump, testified about the payment to Daniels.

### Hope Hicks

Hope Hicks, a former Trump aide, testified about Trump's involvement in the payment to Daniels.

### McConney, Tarasoff, and Franklin

Several executives from the Trump Organization testified about the company's accounting practices and the recording of the payment to Daniels.

### Stormy Daniels

Stormy Daniels testified about her alleged affair with Trump and the payment she received from him.

### Manochio, Menzies, and Westerhout

Several employees of the Trump Organization testified about the company's involvement in the payment to Daniels.

### Dixon, Tomalin, Longstreet, and Jarmel-Schneider

Several employees of American Media, Inc. testified about the company's role in the payment to Daniels.

### Michael Cohen

Michael Cohen testified about his involvement in the payment to Daniels and Trump's alleged direction to make the payment.

## Defense witnesses

### Daniel Sitko

Daniel Sitko, a lawyer who represented Trump in the case, testified about Trump's involvement in the payment to Daniels.

### Robert Costello

Robert Costello, a lawyer who represented Cohen in the case, testified about Cohen's involvement in the payment to Daniels.

## Closing arguments and jury instructions

The prosecution and defense delivered closing arguments to the jury, and the judge provided jury instructions.

## Jury deliberations and verdict

The jury deliberated for several days before delivering a verdict of guilty on the charge of falsifying business records in the first degree.

# Post-trial proceedings

## Gag order

The court lifted the gag order after the verdict was delivered.

## Delayed sentencing hearing

The court scheduled a sentencing hearing for December 2023.

## Immunity ruling

The court ruled that Trump's lawyers would not be granted immunity from prosecution for their role in the case.

## Firearms and liquor licenses

Trump's conviction raised questions about his eligibility to hold firearms and liquor licenses in New York.

## Potential appeal of conviction

Trump's lawyers announced plans to appeal the conviction.

# Reactions

The conviction was met with widespread media coverage and public reaction. Trump's supporters rallied to his defense, while his critics celebrated the verdict.

# See also

* Stormy Daniels–Donald Trump scandal
* Manhattan District Attorney's Office
* Cyrus Vance Jr.

# Notes

This article is based on publicly available information and may not be comprehensive or up-to-date.

# References

None

# External links

None

article:
2023 Men's FIH Hockey World Cup

The 2023 Men's FIH Hockey World Cup will be the 15th edition of the Men's FIH Hockey World Cup, the quadrennial international men's field hockey championship organized by the Fédération Internationale de Hockey (FIH). The tournament will be held in Bhubaneswar and Rourkela, India from January 13 to January 29, 2023.

# Host selection

India was announced as the host country for the 2023 Men's FIH Hockey World Cup by the FIH on November 8, 2019. This will be the fourth time India has hosted the Men's Hockey World Cup, after previously hosting the tournament in 1975, 2010, and 2018.

# Teams

## Qualification

The qualification process for the 2023 Men's FIH Hockey World Cup consisted of five continental championships, which were used as qualification tournaments. The winners of each continental championship qualified directly for the World Cup. Additionally, the top three teams from the 2021-22 FIH Pro League not already qualified through their continental championships also qualified for the World Cup.

## Draw

The draw for the 2023 Men's FIH Hockey World Cup took place on September 8, 2022, in Bhubaneswar, India. The 16 teams were divided into four pools of four teams each, with the teams seeded according to their FIH World Rankings.

## Squads

Each team will name a squad of 18 players for the tournament, with two reserve players also selected. The squads for each team are expected to be announced in December 2022.

# Venues

The 2023 Men's FIH Hockey World Cup will be held at two venues in India: the Kalinga Stadium in Bhubaneswar and the Birsa Munda International Hockey Stadium in Rourkela. The Kalinga Stadium has a seating capacity of 15,000, while the Birsa Munda International Hockey Stadium has a seating capacity of 21,000.

# Umpires

The FIH has appointed a panel of umpires for the 2023 Men's FIH Hockey World Cup. The umpires will be responsible for enforcing the rules and regulations of the game during the tournament.

# First round

The first round of the 2023 Men's FIH Hockey World Cup will consist of a round-robin pool stage, where each team will play the other teams in their pool once. The top three teams from each pool will advance to the second round, while the bottom team from each pool will be eliminated from the tournament.

## Pool A

* Argentina
* Australia
* France
* South Africa

## Pool B

* Belgium
* Germany
* Korea
* Japan

## Pool C

* India
* England
* Spain
* Wales

## Pool D

* Netherlands
* Malaysia
* New Zealand
* Chile

# Classification round

The classification round will determine the final ranking of the teams that did not advance to the second round. The teams that finished fourth in each pool will compete in the 13th-16th place classification, while the teams that finished third in each pool will compete in the 9th-12th place classification.

## 9th–16th place classification

* 9th-12th place semi-finals: 3rd pool A vs 3rd pool D, 3rd pool B vs 3rd pool C
* 13th-16th place semi-finals: 4th pool A vs 4th pool D, 4th pool B vs 4th pool C

## 13th–16th place classification

* 13th-14th place match: Winner 13th-16th place semi-final 1 vs Winner 13th-16th place semi-final 2
* 15th-16th place match: Loser 13th-16th place semi-final 1 vs Loser 13th-16th place semi-final 2

## 9th–12th place classification

* 9th-10th place match: Winner 9th-12th place semi-final 1 vs Winner 9th-12th place semi-final 2
* 11th-12th place match: Loser 9th-12th place semi-final 1 vs Loser 9th-12th place semi-final 2

# Second round

The second round of the 2023 Men's FIH Hockey World Cup will consist of a knockout stage, where the teams will compete in a single-elimination bracket.

## Bracket

* Quarter-finals: 1st pool A vs 2nd pool B, 1st pool B vs 2nd pool A, 1st pool C vs 2nd pool D, 1st pool D vs 2nd pool C
* Semi-finals: Winner quarter-final 1 vs Winner quarter-final 3, Winner quarter-final 2 vs Winner quarter-final 4
* Third and fourth place: Loser semi-final 1 vs Loser semi-final 2
* Final: Winner semi-final 1 vs Winner semi-final 2

## Crossovers

* Crossover 1: 2nd pool A vs 3rd pool B
* Crossover 2: 2nd pool B vs 3rd pool A
* Crossover 3: 2nd pool C vs 3rd pool D
* Crossover 4: 2nd pool D vs 3rd pool C

## Quarter-finals

* Quarter-final 1: Winner crossover 1 vs 1st pool A
* Quarter-final 2: Winner crossover 2 vs 1st pool B
* Quarter-final 3: Winner crossover 3 vs 1st pool C
* Quarter-final 4: Winner crossover 4 vs 1st pool D

## Semi-finals

* Semi-final 1: Winner quarter-final 1 vs Winner quarter-final 3
* Semi-final 2: Winner quarter-final 2 vs Winner quarter-final 4

## Third and fourth place

* Third and fourth place: Loser semi-final 1 vs Loser semi-final 2

## Final

However, their lives take a dramatic turn when they come into contact with a group of Islamic fundamentalists, who slowly brainwash them into adopting their ideology. They are shown to be participating in secret meetings, handling firearms, and even planning terrorist attacks. 2022 Pacific Typhoon Season

The 2022 Pacific typhoon season was the period of the year when most tropical cyclones formed in the Western Pacific Ocean. The season officially began on January 1, 2022, and ended on December 31, 2022. During this time, a total of 30 named storms, 12 typhoons, and 4 super typhoons developed in the region.

# Seasonal forecasts

Before the start of the season, several meteorological agencies issued forecasts predicting the number of tropical cyclones that would form in the Western Pacific. These forecasts were based on various climate models and indicators, such as the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) cycle. In general, the forecasts indicated a near-average to above-average number of tropical cyclones for the season.

# Seasonal summary

## Early season activity

The season began on a quiet note, with only a few weak tropical depressions forming in the first few months. The first named storm, Malakas, developed on March 6, but it remained a tropical storm and did not affect any landmasses. The next named storm, Megi, formed on April 8 and brought heavy rainfall to parts of the Philippines.

## Peak season activity

The peak of the season began in July, with the formation of Typhoon Chaba on June 29. Chaba became the first typhoon of the season and reached peak intensity on July 1. The following weeks saw a flurry of activity, with several named storms developing and affecting various regions. The most notable storms during this period included Typhoon Hinnamnor, which reached super typhoon strength, and Typhoon Muifa, which brought widespread damage to parts of China.

## Late season activity

The late season saw a decrease in activity, with fewer named storms forming. However, some notable storms still developed, including Typhoon Noru, which brought severe damage to parts of Vietnam, and Severe Tropical Storm Nalgae, which caused widespread flooding in the Philippines.

Sonca formed on October 17 and affected parts of Vietnam.

Nesat formed on October 20 and reached peak intensity on October 24.

article:
Rishi Sunak
================

Rishi Sunak is a British politician who served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 2022 to 2024. He has been the Leader of the Opposition since 2024 and the Member of Parliament (MP) for Richmond (Yorks) since 2015. Sunak's tenure as Prime Minister was marked by significant challenges, including the COVID-19 pandemic, an energy crisis, and a cost of living crisis.

Early life and education (1980–2001)
--------------------------------------

Rishi Sunak was born on May 12, 1980, in Southampton, Hampshire, to Yashvir and Usha Sunak. His parents were both of Indian descent, and his father was a general practitioner. Sunak was educated at Stroud School, a preparatory school in Romsey, and later at Winchester College, an independent boarding school in Winchester.

Sunak studied Philosophy, Politics, and Economics (PPE) at Lincoln College, Oxford, where he graduated with a first-class degree. He was later awarded a Fulbright Scholarship to study for an MBA at Stanford University, which he completed in 2006.

Career
--------

### Business career (2001–2015)

After graduating from Oxford, Sunak worked as an analyst at Goldman Sachs, an investment bank, from 2001 to 2004. He later worked at The Children's Investment Fund Management (TCI), a hedge fund, and at Theleme Partners, a hedge fund he co-founded in 2010.

### Backbencher (2015–2018)

Sunak was selected as the Conservative Party candidate for Richmond (Yorks) in 2014. He won the seat in the 2015 general election, succeeding William Hague, who had retired. As a backbencher, Sunak spoke on a range of issues, including education, healthcare, and the economy.

### Local government under-secretary (2018–2019)

In January 2018, Sunak was appointed as the Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Local Government. He was responsible for local government policy, including council funding and planning.

### Chief secretary to the Treasury (2019–2020)

In July 2019, Sunak was appointed as the Chief Secretary to the Treasury, a senior role in the Treasury. He was responsible for public spending, including the Budget and public sector pay.

### Chancellor of the Exchequer (2020–2022)

In February 2020, Sunak was appointed as the Chancellor of the Exchequer, succeeding Sajid Javid. He was the youngest Chancellor since 1892.

#### COVID-19 pandemic

Sunak played a key role in the government's response to the COVID-19 pandemic. He announced a series of measures to support businesses and individuals, including the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS), also known as the furlough scheme.

#### Furlough scheme

The furlough scheme, which was introduced in March 2020, allowed employers to claim a grant from the government to cover 80% of an employee's wages, up to a maximum of £2,500 per month. The scheme was extended several times and was eventually closed in September 2021.

#### Eat Out to Help Out

In July 2020, Sunak announced the Eat Out to Help Out scheme, which provided a discount of up to 50% on meals eaten at participating restaurants, cafes, and pubs. The scheme was designed to support the hospitality industry, which had been severely impacted by the pandemic.

#### Cost of living crisis and energy crisis

Sunak faced significant challenges in 2022, including a cost of living crisis and an energy crisis. He announced a series of measures to support households, including a £15 billion package of support, which included a £400 discount on energy bills.

#### Budgets

As Chancellor, Sunak delivered two Budgets, in March 2020 and March 2021. His Budgets focused on supporting businesses and individuals affected by the pandemic, as well as investing in public services and infrastructure.

#### Other actions

Sunak also took action to support the economy, including cutting VAT on tourism and hospitality, and introducing a new tax on plastic packaging.

#### Resignation

Sunak resigned as Chancellor on July 5, 2022, following a series of controversies, including the Partygate scandal and criticism of his handling of the economy.

### Conservative leadership bids

Sunak stood in the 2022 Conservative Party leadership election, which was won by Liz Truss. He later won the 2022 Conservative Party leadership election, following Truss's resignation.

Premiership (2022–2024)
-------------------------

Sunak became Prime Minister on October 25, 2022, following the resignation of Liz Truss. He formed a new government, which included several senior ministers from the previous government.

### Cabinet

Sunak's Cabinet included several experienced ministers, including Jeremy Hunt, who remained as Chancellor, and James Cleverly, who became Foreign Secretary.

#### Reshuffles

Sunak carried out several reshuffles of his government, including a major reshuffle in February 2023.

### Foreign policy

Sunak's government faced several significant foreign policy challenges, including the ongoing conflict in Ukraine and tensions with China.

#### Immigration

Sunak's government introduced several new policies on immigration, including a new points-based system and increased funding for border control.

#### Russia and Ukraine

Sunak's government provided significant support to Ukraine, including military aid and economic support.

#### Israel and Palestine

Sunak's government maintained a strong relationship with Israel, while also calling for a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

### Local election results

Sunak's government faced significant challenges in local elections, including losses in several key councils.

### 2024 general election and resignation

Sunak called a general election for May 2024, which resulted in a hung parliament. Sunak resigned as Prime Minister on May 15, 2024, and was succeeded by the Leader of the Opposition.

Post-premiership (2024–present)
-------------------------------

### Leader of the Opposition (2024–present)

Sunak became the Leader of the Opposition on May 15, 2024, following his resignation as Prime Minister. He has continued to play a significant role in British politics, including leading the opposition to the new government.

Political positions
-------------------

Sunak has taken several significant political positions, including supporting Brexit and opposing Scottish independence.

Public image
-------------

Sunak's public image has been shaped by his time as Chancellor and Prime Minister. He has been praised for his handling of the economy, but criticized for his role in several controversies.

Personal life
-------------

Sunak is married to Akshata Murty, a businesswoman and daughter of Narayana Murty, the founder of Infosys. The couple has two daughters. Sunak is a practising Hindu and has spoken about the importance of his faith in his life.

article:
James Webb Space Telescope

The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) is a space telescope that was launched in December 2021 by NASA, the European Space Agency (ESA), and the Canadian Space Agency (CSA). It is the largest and most powerful space telescope ever built, designed to conduct infrared astronomy in a wide range of wavelengths. The JWST is named after James E. Webb, the second administrator of NASA, and is considered the successor to the Hubble Space Telescope.

# Features

## Location and orbit

The JWST is located in the second Lagrange point (L2), approximately 1.5 million kilometers from Earth. This location allows the telescope to maintain a stable temperature of around -240°C, which is necessary for its sensitive instruments to function. The L2 point also provides a stable gravitational environment, which minimizes the need for course corrections.

## Sunshield protection

The JWST has a large sunshield that protects its instruments from the heat and light of the Sun. The sunshield is made of five layers of a material called Kapton, which is designed to reflect sunlight and keep the telescope cool. The sunshield is deployed in space and is critical to the operation of the JWST.

## Optics

The JWST has a 6.5-meter primary mirror that is made of 18 hexagonal segments. The mirror is made of beryllium, which is a lightweight and rigid material that is ideal for space telescopes. The mirror is designed to collect and focus infrared radiation, which is then detected by the JWST's instruments.

## Scientific instruments

The JWST has four scientific instruments that are designed to conduct a wide range of astronomical observations. These instruments include the Near-Infrared Camera (NIRCam), the Near-Infrared Spectrograph (NIRSpec), the Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI), and the Fine Guidance Sensor (FGS). Each instrument is designed to study different wavelengths of infrared radiation and to conduct different types of observations.

## Spacecraft bus

The JWST spacecraft bus is the main structure of the telescope, which includes the power and communication systems. The bus is designed to provide power to the JWST's instruments and to communicate with Earth via radio signals. The bus also includes the attitude control system, which is used to point the JWST at its targets.

## Servicing

The JWST is not designed to be serviced by astronauts, unlike the Hubble Space Telescope. However, the JWST does have a limited capability for remote servicing, which allows NASA to update its software and to make minor repairs.

## Software

The JWST software is designed to control the telescope's instruments and to process its data. The software includes the telescope's operating system, which is called the JWST Flight Software. The software also includes the data processing algorithms, which are used to analyze the JWST's observations.

# Comparison with other telescopes

The JWST is the largest and most powerful space telescope ever built, with a primary mirror that is 6.5 meters in diameter. In comparison, the Hubble Space Telescope has a primary mirror that is 2.4 meters in diameter. The JWST is also more sensitive than the Hubble Space Telescope, with a sensitivity that is 10-100 times greater. The JWST is designed to conduct infrared astronomy, whereas the Hubble Space Telescope is designed to conduct visible and ultraviolet astronomy.

# Development history

## Background (development to 2003)

The JWST was first proposed in the 1990s as a successor to the Hubble Space Telescope. The JWST was designed to conduct infrared astronomy, which was a new and rapidly developing field at the time. The JWST was also designed to be more powerful and more sensitive than the Hubble Space Telescope, with a primary mirror that was 6.5 meters in diameter.

## Early development and replanning (2003–2007)

The JWST was officially approved by NASA in 2003, with a planned launch date of 2011. However, the JWST experienced significant delays and cost overruns, which led to a replanning of the project. The JWST's primary mirror was redesigned to be made of 18 hexagonal segments, which reduced its weight and cost.

## Detailed design and construction (2007–2021)

The JWST's detailed design and construction phase began in 2007. The JWST's instruments were designed and built by NASA and its partners, including the ESA and the CSA. The JWST's spacecraft bus was also designed and built during this phase, including its power and communication systems.

## Cost and schedule issues

The JWST experienced significant cost and schedule issues during its development. The JWST's cost increased from an initial estimate of $3.5 billion to a final estimate of $8.7 billion. The JWST's launch date was also delayed several times, from an initial date of 2011 to a final date of 2021.

## Partnership

The JWST is a partnership between NASA, the ESA, and the CSA. The ESA provided the JWST's Ariane 5 rocket, which was used to launch the JWST into space. The CSA provided the JWST's Fine Guidance Sensor, which is used to point the JWST at its targets.

## Naming concerns

The JWST was named after James E. Webb, the second administrator of NASA. However, some astronomers and scientists have raised concerns about the JWST's name, citing Webb's role in the Lavender Scare, a period of persecution of LGBTQ individuals in the 1950s and 1960s.

## Orbit design

The JWST's orbit is designed to be stable and long-lasting, with a minimum lifetime of 5 years. The JWST's orbit is also designed to be thermally stable, with a temperature that is maintained at around -240°C.

## Infrared astronomy

The JWST is designed to conduct infrared astronomy, which is a rapidly developing field. The JWST's instruments are designed to study the infrared radiation that is emitted by stars, galaxies, and other celestial objects.

# Ground support and operations

## Micrometeoroid strike

The JWST experienced a micrometeoroid strike in May 2022, which damaged one of its mirrors. However, the JWST's instruments were not affected, and the telescope was able to continue its observations.

The JWST was launched on December 25, 2021, aboard an Ariane 5 rocket. The JWST was launched from the Guiana Space Centre in French Guiana.

The JWST traveled to its final orbit over the course of several weeks, during which time it deployed its sunshield and its primary mirror. The JWST's sunshield was deployed on December 28, 2021, and its primary mirror was deployed on January 8, 2022.

## Commissioning and testing

The JWST began its commissioning and testing phase in January 2022. The JWST's instruments were turned on and tested, and the telescope's pointing and tracking systems were calibrated.

## Early Release Science program

The JWST's Early Release Science program was designed to provide a limited amount of observation time to astronomers and scientists. The program was designed to demonstrate the JWST's capabilities and to provide a test of its instruments.

## General Observer Program

The JWST's General Observer Program is designed to provide observation time to astronomers and scientists on a competitive basis. The program is designed to support a wide range of scientific research, including the study of stars, galaxies, and other celestial objects.

The JWST released its first full-color images on July 11, 2022. The images showed the galaxy cluster SMACS 0723, the gas giant Jupiter, and the binary star system 2M1207-39.

# Geography

The Woman King

The Woman King is a 2022 historical epic film directed by Gina Prince-Bythewood and written by Dana Stevens. The film is based on the true story of the Agojie, an all-female military unit of the Dahomey Kingdom in West Africa during the 19th century.

#Plot

The film takes place in the 1820s, during the reign of King Ghezo of Dahomey. The kingdom is under threat from neighboring tribes and European colonizers, who seek to exploit the region's rich resources. General Nanisca, a seasoned warrior and leader of the Agojie, trains a new generation of recruits to join the elite fighting force. The story follows Nawi, a young and fiercely independent girl who is forced to flee her home after being rejected by her father. Nawi is taken in by the Agojie and undergoes rigorous training under Nanisca's guidance.

As Nawi grows in strength and skill, she becomes embroiled in the kingdom's politics and battles against external threats. Alongside Nanisca and the Agojie, Nawi fights to protect her new family and the kingdom from those who seek to destroy it. The film's plot is driven by themes of female empowerment, sisterhood, and the struggle for independence and self-determination.

#Cast

The film features a diverse and talented cast, including:

* Viola Davis as General Nanisca
* Thuso Mbedu as Nawi
* Lashana Lynch as Izogie
* Sheila Atim as Amenza
* Hero Fiennes-Tiffin as Santo Ferreira
* John Boyega as King Ghezo

#Production

##Development

The Woman King was in development for several years, with various scripts and directors attached to the project. Gina Prince-Bythewood was eventually brought on board to direct, and she worked closely with writer Dana Stevens to develop the screenplay. The film was produced by Cathy Schulman, Viola Davis, and Julius Tennon, with eOne and TriStar Pictures serving as co-producers.

##Filming

Principal photography took place in South Africa over a period of several months. The film's cinematography was handled by Polly Morgan, who worked closely with Prince-Bythewood to capture the lush landscapes and vibrant culture of West Africa. The film's action sequences were choreographed by stunt coordinator, Danny Hernandez.

##Post-production

Post-production on the film took place in Los Angeles, with editor Terilyn A. Shropshire working closely with Prince-Bythewood to shape the film's narrative and tone. The film's score was composed by Terence Blanchard, who incorporated traditional West African music and instrumentation into the soundtrack.

#Release

The Woman King was released in theaters on September 16, 2022, by Sony Pictures Releasing. The film received a wide release, playing in over 3,000 theaters across the United States. The film also screened at various film festivals, including the Toronto International Film Festival and the African Diaspora International Film Festival.

#Reception

##Box office

The Woman King was a commercial success, grossing over $100 million worldwide. The film performed particularly well in the United States, where it grossed over $70 million in its opening weekend.

##Critical response

The Woman King received widespread critical acclaim, with many praising the film's performances, direction, and cultural significance. The film holds a 94% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on over 200 reviews. On Metacritic, the film has a score of 87 out of 100, based on over 50 reviews.

##Accolades

The Woman King received numerous awards and nominations, including several Academy Award nominations. The film won several NAACP Image Awards, including Outstanding Motion Picture and Outstanding Actress in a Motion Picture for Viola Davis.

#Historical accuracy

The Woman King is based on the true story of the Agojie, an all-female military unit of the Dahomey Kingdom in West Africa during the 19th century. While the film takes some creative liberties with the events and characters, it is largely accurate in its portrayal of the Agojie and their role in the kingdom's history.

##Characters

The film's characters are based on real historical figures, including General Nanisca and King Ghezo. The character of Nawi is fictional, but her story is inspired by the experiences of many women who joined the Agojie.

##Role in slavery

The Dahomey Kingdom was involved in the transatlantic slave trade, and the Agojie played a role in the kingdom's slave raids and trading activities. The film acknowledges this aspect of the kingdom's history, but also highlights the Agojie's resistance to European colonization and their fight for independence and self-determination.

#Controversy

The Woman King has been the subject of some controversy, with some critics accusing the film of glossing over the Dahomey Kingdom's involvement in the slave trade. Others have criticized the film's portrayal of African culture and history, arguing that it reinforces stereotypes and perpetuates a Eurocentric view of the continent.

#Notes

The Woman King is a powerful and timely film that celebrates the strength and resilience of African women. While it takes some creative liberties with the events and characters, it is largely accurate in its portrayal of the Agojie and their role in the kingdom's history.

article:
Music Written in All Major or Minor Keys

Music written in all major or minor keys refers to compositions that cover all 24 possible keys, typically in a set of 24 pieces, one in each key. This concept has been explored by numerous composers throughout history, resulting in a diverse range of works that showcase their technical skill, creativity, and understanding of harmony and tonality.

#Notable Sets that Cover All 24 Keys

Several composers have written notable sets that cover all 24 keys, often in the form of a collection of preludes, fugues, or etudes. These sets are remarkable for their technical complexity, musicality, and historical significance.

##Composers Who Wrote Multiple Sets

Some composers have written multiple sets of pieces covering all 24 keys. For example, Johann Sebastian Bach wrote two sets of preludes and fugues, known as "The Well-Tempered Clavier," Books I and II. Similarly, Dmitri Shostakovich wrote two sets of preludes, Op. 34 and Op. 87, each covering all 24 keys.

#Variants

While many sets of pieces cover all 24 keys, there are also variants that explore different aspects of tonality and harmony.

##Single Pieces that Modulate Through Many Keys

Some composers have written single pieces that modulate through many keys, often creating a sense of tonal ambiguity or uncertainty. For example, Franz Liszt's "La Campanella" is a etude that modulates through numerous keys, creating a sense of virtuosic display and technical complexity.

##Works Covering All Eight Church Modes

In addition to works covering all 24 major and minor keys, some composers have written pieces that explore all eight church modes. For example, Olivier Messiaen's "Modes de Valeur" is a set of pieces that covers all eight church modes, creating a sense of modal experimentation and innovation.

##Other Sets of 24 Pieces

While many sets of pieces cover all 24 major and minor keys, there are also other sets that explore different aspects of tonality and harmony. For example, Igor Stravinsky's "The Firebird" is a ballet that features a set of 24 pieces, each based on a different folk melody or theme.

#Keys

The order of keys in published works can vary, but there are some common patterns and conventions.

##Order of Keys in Published Works

In many published works, the order of keys follows a specific pattern or convention. For example, in Bach's "The Well-Tempered Clavier," the order of keys is based on the circle of fifths, with each key progressing in a clockwise direction. In other works, the order of keys may be based on the composer's personal preference or creative vision.

#History

The concept of music written in all major or minor keys has a rich and complex history, spanning centuries and numerous composers.

##Bach and His Precursors

Johann Sebastian Bach is often credited with perfecting the art of writing music in all major or minor keys. However, there were many precursors to Bach who also explored this concept. For example, Frescobaldi wrote a set of toccatas and partitas that covered all 24 keys, and Sweelinck wrote a set of fantasias that explored all 24 keys.

##After Bach

After Bach, the concept of music written in all major or minor keys continued to evolve and develop.

###18th and 19th Centuries

####1750–1850

During the 18th and 19th centuries, many composers wrote sets of pieces that covered all 24 keys. For example, Haydn wrote a set of sonatas that explored all 24 keys, and Beethoven wrote a set of bagatelles that covered all 24 keys.

####1851–1900

In the late 19th century, the concept of music written in all major or minor keys continued to evolve and develop. For example, Brahms wrote a set of intermezzos that explored all 24 keys, and Chopin wrote a set of nocturnes that covered all 24 keys.

###20th Century

####1901–1950

In the 20th century, the concept of music written in all major or minor keys continued to evolve and develop. For example, Schoenberg wrote a set of pieces for solo piano that explored all 24 keys, and Stravinsky wrote a set of etudes that covered all 24 keys.

####1951–2000

In the second half of the 20th century, the concept of music written in all major or minor keys continued to evolve and develop. For example, Messiaen wrote a set of modes de valeur that explored all 24 keys, and Boulez wrote a set of pieces for solo piano that covered all 24 keys.

###21st Century

In the 21st century, the concept of music written in all major or minor keys continues to evolve and develop. For example, many contemporary composers have written sets of pieces that explore all 24 keys, often using new and innovative techniques and technologies.

#Notes

This article has provided an overview of music written in all major or minor keys, including notable sets that cover all 24 keys, variants, and the history of this concept.

article:
Viktor An
===========

Viktor An is a Russian short track speed skater of South Korean origin. He is a six-time Olympic gold medalist and is widely regarded as one of the greatest short track speed skaters of all time. An's career has been marked by numerous accolades, as well as controversy and conflict with the South Korean skating union and coaches.

Early Life and Education
------------------------

Viktor An was born on November 23, 1985, in Seoul, South Korea. He began skating at the age of six and quickly emerged as a talented young athlete. An's early life was marked by intense training and dedication to his sport.

Career
--------

### 2000s

#### Early Career and the 2002 Winter Olympics

An's early career was marked by rapid progression and success. He made his international debut at the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City, where he won a gold medal in the 1000m event and a bronze medal in the 5000m relay. An's success at the Olympics was a significant factor in his rise to prominence in the short track speed skating world.

#### National Team 'Recommendation System'

In South Korea, the national team selection process is based on a "recommendation system," where coaches and officials recommend athletes for selection to the national team. An's success at the Olympics led to him being recommended for the national team, and he quickly became a key member of the Korean team.

### 2002–2005, KNSU and Non-KNSU

Between 2002 and 2005, An continued to compete at the highest level, winning numerous World Cup events and World Championships titles. However, his relationship with the Korea Skating Union (KNSU) began to deteriorate, and he faced criticism from coaches and officials.

### 2005, Conflict with Korea Skating Union

In 2005, An's conflict with the KNSU came to a head. He was criticized by coaches and officials for his training methods and his decision to compete in non-KNSU events. An responded by stating that he felt stifled by the KNSU's rigid training system and that he needed to compete in other events to improve his skills.

### 2006 Winter Olympics

At the 2006 Winter Olympics in Torino, An won two gold medals and one bronze medal. However, his success was marred by controversy, as he was involved in a collision with American skater Apolo Anton Ohno in the 5000m relay final.

### After Torino

After the 2006 Olympics, An's relationship with the KNSU continued to deteriorate. He faced criticism from coaches and officials, and he began to explore options for competing outside of the KNSU system.

### Injury in Early 2008

In early 2008, An suffered a serious injury that kept him out of competition for several months. The injury was a significant setback, but An was determined to return to competition and continue his career.

### 2010s

#### 2010, Conflict with Korea Skating Union

In 2010, An's conflict with the KNSU reached a boiling point. He was involved in a dispute with coaches and officials over his training methods and his decision to compete in non-KNSU events. The dispute led to An being suspended from the national team, and he was forced to consider alternative options for continuing his career.

#### Naturalization to Russia

In 2011, An announced that he would be naturalizing to Russia and competing for the Russian national team. The decision was a significant shock, as An had been a key member of the Korean team for many years.

#### 2011, Conflict with the South Korean Coaches

article:
Chess World Cup 2023

The Chess World Cup 2023 is a 128-player single-elimination chess tournament that will take place from July 28 to August 25, 2023, in Baku, Azerbaijan. The tournament is part of the qualification cycle for the World Chess Championship 2024.

# Format

The tournament will feature 128 players, who will compete in a single-elimination format. Each match will consist of two classical games, with the winner being the first player to score 1.5 points or more. If the score is tied after two games, the players will proceed to a tiebreaker, which will consist of two rapid games, followed by two blitz games, and finally an Armageddon game if necessary.

## Schedule

The tournament is scheduled to take place from July 28 to August 25, 2023. The rounds will be held as follows:

* Round 1: July 28-30
* Round 2: July 31-August 2
* Round 3: August 3-5
* Round 4: August 6-8
* Round 5: August 9-11
* Round 6: August 12-14
* Round 7: August 15-17
* Round 8: August 19-21

## Prize money

The total prize fund for the tournament is $1,000,000, with the winner receiving $110,000. The prizes will be distributed as follows:

* Winner: $110,000
* Runner-up: $55,000
* Third place: $35,000
* Fourth place: $20,000
* Round 4 losers: $15,000 each
* Round 3 losers: $10,000 each
* Round 2 losers: $5,000 each
* Round 1 losers: $2,500 each

# Participants

The tournament will feature 128 players, who will qualify through various means.

## Qualifier explanation

The qualification process for the Chess World Cup 2023 is as follows:

* The top 15 players in the FIDE world rankings as of January 2023 will qualify directly.
* The winners of the 2022 Continental Championships will qualify.
* The top 4 players in the FIDE Grand Prix 2022 will qualify.
* The top 4 players in the FIDE Women's Grand Prix 2022 will qualify.
* The top 2 players in the FIDE Junior World Championship 2022 will qualify.
* The top 2 players in the FIDE Girls Junior World Championship 2022 will qualify.
* The top 18 players in the FIDE world rankings as of January 2023, who have not already qualified, will qualify.
* The remaining 72 players will qualify through the FIDE World Cup Qualifier 2023, which will take place in May 2023.

## Replacements

In case of a player's withdrawal, they will be replaced by the next available player in the FIDE world rankings as of January 2023.

article:
L. Ron Hubbard
================

Lafayette Ronald Hubbard, more commonly known as L. Ron Hubbard, was an American author, philosopher, and the founder of the Church of Scientology. Born on March 13, 1911, in Tilden, Nebraska, Hubbard is best known for developing the self-help system called Dianetics, which later evolved into the Church of Scientology. His life was marked by a mix of literary success, military service, and the creation of a spiritual movement that has been the subject of controversy and scrutiny.

Life
=====

### Before Dianetics

#### Pre-war fiction

Hubbard's early life was marked by a love for writing and adventure. He began writing at an early age and was heavily influenced by the science fiction and fantasy authors of his time, such as H.G. Wells and Jules Verne. In the 1930s, Hubbard started writing for pulp magazines, publishing numerous short stories and novels in the science fiction and fantasy genres. Some of his notable works from this period include the novel "Fear" and the short story "The Dangerous Dimension."

#### Military career

In 1941, Hubbard joined the United States Navy, where he served during World War II. He was assigned to various posts, including the Philippines, Australia, and the United States. Hubbard's military career was marked by controversy, with some claims suggesting that he was injured in combat and others indicating that he was not. Despite this, Hubbard was awarded several medals, including the Purple Heart.

#### After the war

After the war, Hubbard returned to writing, but he became increasingly interested in the field of psychology and the human mind. He began to develop his own theories about the nature of consciousness and the human condition, which would eventually become the basis for Dianetics.

### In the Dianetics era

In 1950, Hubbard published his book "Dianetics: The Modern Science of Mental Health," which introduced his concept of the "reactive mind" and the "auditing" process. The book was a commercial success, and Hubbard quickly became a prominent figure in the field of self-help and personal development. He established the Hubbard Dianetic Research Foundation, which offered auditing services and trained auditors in the Dianetics method.

### Pivot to Scientology

In the early 1950s, Hubbard began to develop his ideas further, incorporating elements of science fiction, philosophy, and spirituality into his work. He introduced the concept of the "thetan," a spiritual being that is trapped in the physical body, and developed the idea of the "eight dynamics," which describe the different aspects of human existence. This marked the beginning of Scientology, which would eventually replace Dianetics as Hubbard's primary focus.

### In the Church of Scientology era

In 1954, Hubbard established the first Church of Scientology in Los Angeles, California. The church quickly grew, and Hubbard became a charismatic leader, attracting thousands of followers. He established a hierarchical structure for the church, with himself at the top as the "Source" of Scientology. Hubbard also developed the concept of the "Operating Thetan," a spiritual state that can be achieved through advanced auditing and training.

### In the Sea Org era

In the late 1960s, Hubbard established the Sea Organization, a paramilitary group within the Church of Scientology. The Sea Org was responsible for managing the church's affairs and enforcing Hubbard's policies. Hubbard himself became increasingly reclusive, living on a ship called the Apollo, where he wrote and lectured on Scientology.

### In hiding

In the 1970s and 1980s, Hubbard's health began to decline, and he became increasingly isolated. He lived in hiding, using various pseudonyms and disguises to avoid detection. Despite his poor health, Hubbard continued to write and dictate policies for the Church of Scientology until his death on January 24, 1986.

Sources and doctrines
=====================

Hubbard's work draws on a wide range of sources, including science fiction, philosophy, psychology, and spirituality. He was influenced by authors such as Aleister Crowley, Sigmund Freud, and Carl Jung, and incorporated elements of their ideas into his own work. Hubbard's doctrines are based on his concept of the "reactive mind" and the "thetan," and he developed a complex system of auditing and training to help individuals achieve spiritual enlightenment.

False biographical claims
=========================

Hubbard made several false claims about his life and achievements, including claims that he was a nuclear physicist, a war hero, and a graduate of George Washington University. These claims have been widely debunked, and Hubbard's actual life and achievements are significantly less impressive.

Legacy
=======

### In Scientology

Hubbard's legacy within the Church of Scientology is immense. He is revered as the "Source" of Scientology, and his teachings are considered sacred. The church continues to use Hubbard's methods and materials, and his writings are considered authoritative.

### In popular culture

Hubbard's influence can also be seen in popular culture, particularly in the fields of science fiction and fantasy. His ideas about the nature of consciousness and the human condition have influenced authors such as Philip K. Dick and Robert A. Heinlein. Hubbard's work has also been referenced in music, film, and television, often as a symbol of cultish or pseudoscientific thinking.

Select works
=============

* "Fear" (1940)
* "The Dangerous Dimension" (1938)
* "Dianetics: The Modern Science of Mental Health" (1950)
* "Science of Survival" (1951)
* "The Creation of Human Ability" (1954)
* "Introduction to Scientology Ethics" (1965)

See also
=========

article:
2022 Johor state election

The 2022 Johor state election was held on 12 March 2022 to elect the 56 members of the Johor State Legislative Assembly, the legislature of the Malaysian state of Johor. The election was called following the dissolution of the Johor State Legislative Assembly on 22 January 2022. The election was held concurrently with the early polling day for postal and advance voters on 8 March 2022.

# Election cycles

The Johor state election is held every five years, as per the Malaysian Constitution. The previous election was held in 2018, and the next election is scheduled to be held in 2027, unless the assembly is dissolved earlier.

# Electoral system

The Johor State Legislative Assembly is a unicameral legislature, meaning it has only one chamber. The 56 members of the assembly are elected through a first-past-the-post system, where the candidate with the most votes in each constituency wins the seat.

# Constituencies

The 56 constituencies in Johor are divided into 26 parliamentary constituencies. Each parliamentary constituency has two to three state constituencies.

# Composition before dissolution

Before the dissolution of the assembly, the composition of the Johor State Legislative Assembly was as follows:

* Barisan Nasional (BN): 34 seats
* Pakatan Harapan (PH): 27 seats
* Perikatan Nasional (PN): 1 seat
* Independent: 1 seat

## Events from the Dissolution of the Johor State Legislative Assembly to the Issue of the Writ of Election (22 January to 9 February 2022)

* 22 January 2022: The Johor State Legislative Assembly was dissolved by the Sultan of Johor, Sultan Ibrahim Ismail, on the advice of the Menteri Besar of Johor, Hasni Mohammad.
* 25 January 2022: The Election Commission of Malaysia announced that the state election would be held on 12 March 2022.
* 9 February 2022: The writ of election was issued, marking the beginning of the campaign period.

## Events from the Issue of the Writ of Election to the Nomination Day (10 to 26 February 2022)

* 10 February 2022: The nomination period began, allowing candidates to submit their nomination papers.
* 26 February 2022: The nomination period ended, and the candidates were announced.

## Events from the Nomination Day to the Early Polling Day for Postal and Advance Voters & Campaigning Period (27 February to 12 March 2022)

* 27 February 2022: The campaign period began, allowing candidates to campaign and hold rallies.
* 8 March 2022: Early polling day for postal and advance voters was held.
* 12 March 2022: Polling day was held, and the results were announced.

# Electoral candidates

A total of 234 candidates contested in the election, representing 15 parties and 1 independent candidate.

# Results

## By parliamentary constituency

* Johor Bahru: Pakatan Harapan won 4 out of 5 seats
* Pontian: Barisan Nasional won 2 out of 3 seats
* Batu Pahat: Barisan Nasional won 2 out of 3 seats
* Kluang: Pakatan Harapan won 2 out of 3 seats
* Segamat: Barisan Nasional won 2 out of 3 seats
* Muar: Barisan Nasional won 2 out of 3 seats
* Ledang: Pakatan Harapan won 2 out of 3 seats
* Bakri: Barisan Nasional won 2 out of 3 seats
* Simpang Renggam: Barisan Nasional won 2 out of 3 seats
* Sembrong: Barisan Nasional won 2 out of 3 seats
* Mersing: Barisan Nasional won 2 out of 3 seats
* Tenggara: Barisan Nasional won 2 out of 3 seats
* Kota Tinggi: Barisan Nasional won 2 out of 3 seats
* Pengerang: Barisan Nasional won 2 out of 3 seats
* Tebrau: Pakatan Harapan won 2 out of 3 seats
* Pasir Gudang: Pakatan Harapan won 2 out of 3 seats
* Johor Bahru: Pakatan Harapan won 2 out of 3 seats
* Pulai: Barisan Nasional won 2 out of 3 seats
* Gelang Patah: Pakatan Harapan won 2 out of 3 seats
* Kulai: Pakatan Harapan won 2 out of 3 seats

## Seats that changed allegiance

* 23 seats changed allegiance from Pakatan Harapan to Barisan Nasional
* 2 seats changed allegiance from Barisan Nasional to Pakatan Harapan
* 1 seat changed allegiance from Perikatan Nasional to Barisan Nasional
* 1 seat changed allegiance from Independent to Barisan Nasional

# Election pendulum

The election pendulum shows the seats that changed allegiance and the margin of the winning candidate.

# Departing incumbents

A total of 23 incumbents did not contest in the election or lost their seats.

# Controversies and issues

* The election was held during the COVID-19 pandemic, which raised concerns about the safety of voters and candidates.
* The Election Commission of Malaysia was criticized for its handling of the election, including the decision to hold the election during the pandemic.
* There were reports of vote-buying and other forms of electoral malpractice.

# Aftermath

* The results of the election were widely seen as a victory for Barisan Nasional, which regained control of the Johor State Legislative Assembly.
* The Pakatan Harapan coalition was criticized for its poor performance in the election, which was seen as a setback for the opposition.
* The Perikatan Nasional coalition failed to make significant gains in the election, which was seen as a disappointment for the party.

# See also

* 2022 Malaysian state elections
* 2022 Malaysian general election
* Johor State Legislative Assembly
* Election Commission of Malaysia

# Notes

article:
2023 Israeli Judicial Reform

The 2023 Israeli judicial reform is a proposed set of amendments to the Israeli judicial system, introduced by the government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in January 2023. The reform aims to limit the power of the Israeli Supreme Court and give the government more control over the appointment of judges and the interpretation of laws. The proposed changes have sparked intense debate and controversy within Israel and internationally, with proponents arguing that the reform is necessary to restore balance to the Israeli system of government and opponents claiming that it would undermine democracy and the rule of law.

#Background

##Israeli Supreme Court and judicial review

The Israeli Supreme Court is the highest court in Israel, with the power to interpret laws and decide on their constitutionality. The court has played a significant role in shaping Israeli law and politics, often serving as a check on the power of the government. The court's ability to review and strike down laws has been a source of controversy, with some arguing that it oversteps its bounds and interferes with the democratic process.

##1992 Constitutional Revolution and its discontents

In 1992, the Israeli Supreme Court, led by Chief Justice Aharon Barak, introduced a series of decisions that established the court as a powerful force in Israeli politics. The court's decisions, known as the "Constitutional Revolution," held that the court had the power to review and strike down laws that it deemed unconstitutional. While the decisions were hailed by some as a victory for democracy and human rights, others saw them as an attempt by the court to impose its own vision on the country.

##2018–2022 Israeli political crisis and 2022 legislative election

In 2018, Israel entered a period of political crisis, marked by a series of inconclusive elections and the inability of any party to form a stable government. The crisis was fueled by a series of corruption scandals, including one involving Prime Minister Netanyahu. In the 2022 legislative election, Netanyahu's Likud party won the most seats, but was unable to form a government without the support of other parties. The election marked a turning point in Israeli politics, with the newly formed government, led by Netanyahu, vowing to implement significant changes to the judicial system.

#Legislative history

##HCJ 5658/23 Movement for Quality Government in Israel v. Knesset (2024)

In response to the proposed reforms, a petition was filed with the Supreme Court, challenging the constitutionality of the amendments. The petition, filed by the Movement for Quality Government in Israel, argued that the reforms would undermine the independence of the judiciary and the rule of law. The court's decision, expected in 2024, will have significant implications for the future of the Israeli judicial system.

#Proposed changes

##Judicial selection

###Current system

Under the current system, judges are selected by a nine-member committee, composed of three Supreme Court justices, two ministers, two members of the Knesset, and two representatives of the Israel Bar Association. The committee selects candidates based on their qualifications and experience.

###Proposed system

The proposed reform would give the government more control over the appointment of judges, allowing it to nominate candidates without the approval of the Supreme Court. The reform would also reduce the number of Supreme Court justices on the selection committee.

###Arguments in favor of the reform

Proponents of the reform argue that the current system is biased towards appointing judges who are out of touch with the views of the Israeli public. They claim that the reform would allow for the appointment of more diverse and representative judges.

###Arguments against the reform

Opponents of the reform argue that it would undermine the independence of the judiciary and allow the government to appoint judges who are loyal only to the ruling party. They claim that the reform would lead to a politicization of the judiciary and undermine the rule of law.

##Government legal advisors

The proposed reform would give government ministers the power to appoint their own legal advisors, rather than relying on the Attorney-General. This would allow ministers to receive advice that is more in line with their own views, rather than being bound by the advice of the Attorney-General.

##Constitutional review

The proposed reform would limit the power of the Supreme Court to review and strike down laws. The reform would establish a new process for reviewing laws, which would involve a panel of experts and would be more limited in scope than the current system.

##Override clause

The proposed reform would introduce an "override clause," which would allow the Knesset to override Supreme Court decisions with a majority of 61 votes. This would give the government more power to implement its policies, even if they are challenged by the court.

##Abolition of "unreasonableness" grounds

The proposed reform would abolish the "unreasonableness" grounds for challenging laws, which have been used by the Supreme Court to strike down laws that it deems unreasonable or disproportionate.

###Arguments in favor of the reform

Proponents of the reform argue that the "unreasonableness" grounds have been used too broadly by the court, and have led to the striking down of laws that are reasonable and necessary.

###Arguments against the reform

Opponents of the reform argue that the abolition of the "unreasonableness" grounds would undermine the ability of the court to protect individual rights and would lead to the implementation of arbitrary and unreasonable laws.

##Status of the Attorney-General

The proposed reform would reduce the power of the Attorney-General, who would no longer have the authority to advise government ministers on legal matters. The Attorney-General would be limited to advising the government on matters of law and would not have the power to challenge government decisions.

#Reactions

##National

The proposed reforms have sparked intense debate within Israel, with proponents arguing that they are necessary to restore balance to the Israeli system of government and opponents claiming that they would undermine democracy and the rule of law.

##International

The proposed reforms have also been criticized internationally, with many countries and organizations expressing concern about the impact on democracy and human rights.

##Connection to the Israeli–Palestinian conflict

The proposed reforms have also been linked to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, with some arguing that they would undermine the ability of the court to protect the rights of Palestinians and others claiming that they would help to promote a more just and equitable society.

#Suspension and overruling

The proposed reforms have been suspended pending a decision by the Supreme Court, which is expected to rule on the constitutionality of the amendments. If the court rules that the reforms are unconstitutional, they may be overruled and the current system restored.

#See also

* Israeli Supreme Court

* Constitutional Revolution
* 2022 Israeli legislative election

article:
Technoblade
================

Technoblade was an American YouTuber and streamer known for his gaming content, particularly in the sandbox-style video game Minecraft. He initially gained fame on YouTube, where he posted videos of himself playing Minecraft and other games, often with a comedic commentary. He later transitioned to live streaming on platforms such as Twitch, where he built a large and dedicated following.

Internet career
---------------

Technoblade began his YouTube channel in 2012, initially posting videos of himself playing Minecraft. He quickly gained popularity due to his entertaining commentary and skillful gameplay. Over time, he expanded his content to include other games, such as Terraria and Roblox. However, Minecraft remained his primary focus, and he became one of the most well-known and respected Minecraft YouTubers.

In 2019, Technoblade began live streaming on Twitch, where he built a large following. He streamed a variety of games, including Minecraft, Among Us, and other popular titles. His streams were known for their high energy and entertaining commentary, often featuring collaborations with other popular streamers.

Technoblade was also known for his charity work, often participating in fundraising events and livestreams for various causes. In 2020, he participated in a 24-hour livestream to raise money for cancer research, raising over $100,000.

Personal life
-------------

Little is known about Technoblade's personal life, as he kept it largely private. However, in a 2020 interview, he revealed that he was a college student, studying computer science. He also mentioned that he was a self-taught programmer and had a strong interest in technology.

Technoblade was known for his dry sense of humor and sarcastic wit, often incorporating humor into his streams and videos. He was also known for his strong work ethic, often streaming for long hours and posting multiple videos per week.

Cancer diagnosis and death
---------------------------

In August 2021, Technoblade announced that he had been diagnosed with cancer. He revealed that he had been experiencing symptoms for several months prior to the diagnosis and had undergone surgery to remove the tumor.

Despite his diagnosis, Technoblade continued to stream and post videos, often using his platform to raise awareness and funds for cancer research. However, in June 2022, he announced that his cancer had progressed and that he would be taking a hiatus from streaming to focus on his health.

On June 30, 2022, Technoblade's family announced that he had passed away, surrounded by his loved ones. The news of his passing shocked the gaming community, with many fans and fellow streamers paying tribute to him on social media.

## Reactions and tributes

The news of Technoblade's passing sparked an outpouring of tributes and condolences from the gaming community. Many fans and fellow streamers shared their favorite memories of Technoblade, praising his kindness, generosity, and dedication to his craft.

The Minecraft community was particularly affected by his passing, with many players creating tributes and memorials in his honor. The game's developers, Mojang Studios, also released a statement paying tribute to Technoblade, calling him "a true Minecraft legend."

Notes
-----

* Technoblade's real name was not publicly known, and he preferred to keep it private.
* Despite his passing, Technoblade's YouTube channel and Twitch stream remain active, with many fans continuing to watch and share his content.

References
----------

*None*
