article:
FIFA World Cup Records and Statistics

The FIFA World Cup is an international soccer tournament held every four years, featuring national teams from all over the world. The tournament has a rich history, and numerous records have been set over the years. This article aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the records and statistics of the FIFA World Cup.

# List of Tournaments

The FIFA World Cup has been held 22 times since its inception in 1930. The tournament has been hosted by 17 different countries, with Brazil, Germany, and Italy being the most successful teams.

# Overall Team Records

This section provides an overview of the overall team records in the FIFA World Cup.

## Most Titles

Brazil holds the record for the most titles won, with five World Cup victories (1958, 1962, 1970, 1994, and 2002). Germany and Italy are second, with four titles each.

## Most Finishes in the Top Two

Germany has finished in the top two most times, with a total of eight appearances in the final (six titles and two runner-up finishes).

## Most Second-Place Finishes

Germany and the Netherlands are tied for the most second-place finishes, with three each.

## Most World Cup Appearances

Brazil has appeared in the most World Cups, with 22 appearances.

## Most Consecutive Championships

Italy holds the record for the most consecutive championships, with two titles in 1934 and 1938.

## Most Consecutive Finishes in the Top Two

Germany has finished in the top two most consecutive times, with four appearances in the final from 1982 to 1990.

## Longest Gap Between Successive Titles

The longest gap between successive titles is 44 years, achieved by Spain, who won the World Cup in 2010 after a 44-year drought.

## Longest Gap Between Successive Appearances in the Top Two

The longest gap between successive appearances in the top two is 56 years, achieved by the Netherlands, who appeared in the final in 1974 and then again in 2010.

## Longest Gap Between Successive Appearances at the FIFA World Cup

The longest gap between successive appearances at the FIFA World Cup is 48 years, achieved by Egypt, who appeared in the World Cup in 1934 and then again in 1990.

## Most Consecutive Failed Qualification Attempts

The most consecutive failed qualification attempts is 20, achieved by Luxembourg, who failed to qualify for the World Cup from 1964 to 2002.

## Worst Finish by Defending Champions

The worst finish by defending champions is a group stage exit, achieved by France in 2002 and Spain in 2014.

# Players

This section provides an overview of the player records in the FIFA World Cup.

## Most Appearances

The record for most appearances in the World Cup is held by Antonio Carbajal of Mexico and Lothar Matthäus of Germany, with 25 appearances each.

## Most Championships

The record for most championships won by a player is held by Pelé of Brazil, with three titles (1958, 1962, and 1970).

## Most Appearances in a World Cup Final

The record for most appearances in a World Cup final is held by Mário Zagallo of Brazil and Franz Beckenbauer of Germany, with three appearances each.

## Youngest Player

The youngest player to appear in the World Cup is Norman Whiteside of Northern Ireland, who played in the 1982 World Cup at the age of 17 years and 41 days.

## Youngest Player in a Final

The youngest player to appear in a World Cup final is Pelé of Brazil, who played in the 1958 World Cup final at the age of 17 years and 249 days.

## Oldest Player

The oldest player to appear in the World Cup is Essam El-Hadary of Egypt, who played in the 2018 World Cup at the age of 45 years and 161 days.

## Oldest Player in a Final

The oldest player to appear in a World Cup final is Dino Zoff of Italy, who played in the 1982 World Cup final at the age of 40 years and 133 days.

# Goalscoring

This section provides an overview of the goalscoring records in the FIFA World Cup.

## Individual

### Top Goalscorers

The record for most goals scored in the World Cup is held by Miroslav Klose of Germany, with 16 goals.

### Most Goals Scored in a Single Tournament

The record for most goals scored in a single tournament is held by Just Fontaine of France, with 13 goals in the 1958 World Cup.

### Most Goals Scored in a Match

The record for most goals scored in a match is held by Oleg Salenko of Russia, with five goals against Cameroon in the 1994 World Cup.

### Most Goals Scored in a Final Match

The record for most goals scored in a final match is held by Kylian Mbappé of France, with four goals against Croatia in the 2018 World Cup final.

### Most Goals Scored in Final Matches (Overall)

The record for most goals scored in final matches is held by Vavá of Brazil, with three goals in the 1958 and 1962 World Cup finals.

### Most Consecutive Matches Scored In

The record for most consecutive matches scored in is held by Jürgen Klinsmann of Germany, with five matches in the 1994 World Cup.

### Most Tournaments Scored In

The record for most tournaments scored in is held by Miroslav Klose of Germany, with four tournaments (2002, 2006, 2010, and 2014).

### Milestone Goals

The record for milestone goals is held by Miroslav Klose of Germany, with the 2000th goal in World Cup history.

### Olympic Goals

The record for most Olympic goals is held by Hermann Brandt of Germany, with three goals in the 1912 Olympic Games.

### Youngest Goalscorer

The youngest goalscorer in the World Cup is Pelé of Brazil, who scored against Wales in the 1958 World Cup at the age of 17 years and 239 days.

### Youngest Goalscorer in a Final

The youngest goalscorer in a World Cup final is Pelé of Brazil, who scored against Sweden in the 1958 World Cup final at the age of 17 years and 249 days.

### Oldest Goalscorer

The oldest goalscorer in the World Cup is Roger Milla of Cameroon, who scored against Russia in the 1994 World Cup at the age of 42 years and 39 days.

### Oldest Goalscorer at the Knock-Out Round

The oldest goalscorer at the knock-out round is Cristiano Ronaldo of Portugal, who scored against Ukraine in the 2006 World Cup at the age of 39 years and 124 days.

### Oldest Goalscorer in a Final

The oldest goalscorer in a World Cup final is Nils Liedholm of Sweden, who scored against Brazil in the 1958 World Cup final at the age of 35 years and 263 days.

### Oldest Goalscorer in a Victorious Final

The oldest goalscorer in a victorious World Cup final is Didier Drogba of Ivory Coast, who scored against Brazil in the 2010 World Cup at the age of 34 years and 166 days.

### Fastest Goal

The fastest goal in the World Cup is held by Hakan Sukur of Turkey, who scored against South Korea in the 2002 World Cup at 11 seconds.

### Fastest Goal in a Final

The fastest goal in a World Cup final is held by Pelé of Brazil, who scored against Sweden in the 1958 World Cup final at 4 minutes and 17 seconds.

### Latest Goal in Regular Time

The latest goal in regular time is held by Abby Wambach of the United States, who scored against Brazil in the 2011 World Cup at 122 minutes and 1 second.

## Team

### Biggest Wins

The record for biggest wins is held by Hungary, who defeated El Salvador 10-1 in the 1982 World Cup.

### Biggest Win in a Final

The record for biggest win in a final is held by Brazil, who defeated Sweden 5-2 in the 1958 World Cup final.

### Highest Scoring Matches

The record for highest scoring matches is held by Austria and Switzerland, who drew 7-5 in the 1954 World Cup.

### Most Goals in a Tournament

The record for most goals in a tournament is held by France, who scored 23 goals in the 1998 World Cup.

### Top Scoring Teams by Tournament

The record for top scoring teams by tournament is held by Hungary, who scored 27 goals in the 1954 World Cup.

## Tournament

### Most Goals Scored in a Tournament

The record for most goals scored in a tournament is held by the 1998 World Cup, with 171 goals.

### Fewest Goals Scored in a Tournament

The record for fewest goals scored in a tournament is held by the 1930 World Cup, with 70 goals.

### Most Goals per Match in a Tournament

The record for most goals per match in a tournament is held by the 1954 World Cup, with an average of 5.38 goals per match.

### Fewest Goals per Match in a Tournament

The record for fewest goals per match in a tournament is held by the 1990 World Cup, with an average of 2.21 goals per match.

## Own Goals

The record for most own goals is held by Mexico, with 11 own goals.

# Assists

This section provides an overview of the assist records in the FIFA World Cup.

## Most Assists

The record for most assists is held by Pelé of Brazil, with 10 assists.

## Most Assists in a Tournament

The record for most assists in a tournament is held by Thomas Müller of Germany, with 6 assists in the 2010 World Cup.

## Most Tournaments Assisted In

The record for most tournaments assisted in is held by Miroslav Klose of Germany, with 4 tournaments (2002, 2006, 2010, and 2014).

## Most Assists Provided in a Match

The record for most assists provided in a match is held by Pelé of Brazil, with 4 assists against Sweden in the 1958 World Cup.

## Most Assists Provided in Final Matches

The record for most assists provided in final matches is held by Pelé of Brazil, with 2 assists in the 1958 and 1962 World Cup finals.

# Goal Contributions

This section provides an overview of the goal contribution records in the FIFA World Cup.

## Most Goal Contributions

The record for most goal contributions is held by Miroslav Klose of Germany, with 26 goal contributions (16 goals and 10 assists).

## Most Goal Contributions in a Tournament

The record for most goal contributions in a tournament is held by Thomas Müller of Germany, with 10 goal contributions (5 goals and 5 assists) in the 2010 World Cup.

# Penalty Shoot-Outs

This section provides an overview of the penalty shoot-out records in the FIFA World Cup.

## Most Penalty Shoot-Outs

The record for most penalty shoot-outs is held by Germany, with 4 penalty shoot-outs.

## Most Penalty Shoot-Outs Won

The record for most penalty shoot-outs won is held by Germany, with 3 penalty shoot-outs won.

## Most Penalty Shoot-Outs Lost

The record for most penalty shoot-outs lost is held by England, with 2 penalty shoot-outs lost.

# Goalkeeping

This section provides an overview of the goalkeeping records in the FIFA World Cup.

## Most Clean Sheets

The record for most clean sheets is held by Fabien Barthez of France, with 10 clean sheets.

## Most Consecutive Minutes without Conceding a Goal

The record for most consecutive minutes without conceding a goal is held by Walter Zenga of Italy, with 517 minutes.

## Most Goals Conceded

The record for most goals conceded is held by Antonio Carbajal of Mexico, with 25 goals conceded.

## Most Goals Conceded in a Tournament

The record for most goals conceded in a tournament is held by South Africa, with 13 goals conceded in the 2010 World Cup.

## Fewest Goals Conceded in a Tournament

The record for fewest goals conceded in a tournament is held by Italy, with 2 goals conceded in the 2006 World Cup.

## Fewest Goals Conceded in a Tournament for the Eventual Winners

The record for fewest goals conceded in a tournament for the eventual winners is held by Italy, with 2 goals conceded in the 2006 World Cup.

## Most Saves in One Match

The record for most saves in one match is held by Guillermo Ochoa of Mexico, with 13 saves against Brazil in the 2014 World Cup.

## Most Penalties Saved (Excluding Penalty Shoot-Outs)

The record for most penalties saved is held by Gianluigi Buffon of Italy, with 2 penalties saved.

## Most Penalties Saved in One Penalty Shoot-Out

The record for most penalties saved in one penalty shoot-out is held by Sergio Goycochea of Argentina, with 2 penalties saved.

## Most Penalties Saved Overall in Penalty Shoot-Outs

The record for most penalties saved overall in penalty shoot-outs is held by Sergio Goycochea of Argentina, with 4 penalties saved.

# Coaching

This section provides an overview of the coaching records in the FIFA World Cup.

## Most Matches Coached

The record for most matches coached is held by Helmut Schön of Germany, with 25 matches coached.

## Most Matches Won

The record for most matches won is held by Helmut Schön of Germany, with 16 matches won.

## Most Tournaments Won

The record for most tournaments won is held by Vittorio Pozzo of Italy, with 2 tournaments won (1934 and 1938).

## Most Tournaments as a Coach

The record for most tournaments as a coach is held by Carlos Alberto Parreira of Brazil, with 6 tournaments (1982, 1994, 1998, 2002, 2006, and 2010).

## Most Different Nations Coached

The record for most different nations coached is held by Bora Milutinović of Serbia, with 5 different nations coached (Mexico, Costa Rica, United States, Nigeria, and China).

## Most Consecutive Tournaments as a Coach

The record for most consecutive tournaments as a coach is held by Luiz Felipe Scolari of Brazil, with 4 consecutive tournaments (2002, 2006, 2010, and 2014).

## Most Consecutive Tournaments as a Coach with the Same Team

The record for most consecutive tournaments as a coach with the same team is held by Vicente del Bosque of Spain, with 3 consecutive tournaments (2010, 2014, and 2018).

## Youngest Coach

The record for youngest coach is held by Juan José Tramutola of Argentina, who coached at the age of 27 in the 1930 World Cup.

## Youngest Coach of a World Cup Winning Team

The record for youngest coach of a World Cup winning team is held by Aime Jacquet of France, who won the World Cup at the age of 54 in the 1998 World Cup.

## Oldest Coach

The record for oldest coach is held by Otto Rehhagel of Germany, who coached at the age of 71 in the 2010 World Cup.

## Oldest Coach of a World Cup Winning Team

The record for oldest coach of a World Cup winning team is held by Luiz Felipe Scolari of Brazil, who won the World Cup at the age of 65 in the 2014 World Cup.

# Refereeing

This section provides an overview of the refereeing records in the FIFA World Cup.

The record for most tournaments is held by Joël Quiniou of France, with 3 tournaments (1986, 1990, and 1994).

## Fastest Caution

The record for fastest caution is held by José Batista of Uruguay, who was cautioned after 1 minute in the 1986 World Cup.

Malaysia at the 2023 SEA Games

The 2023 Southeast Asian Games, officially known as the 32nd Southeast Asian Games, is a regional multi-sport event that will take place in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, from 5 to 17 May 2023. Malaysia will participate in the games, sending a contingent of athletes to compete in various sports.

# Background

Malaysia has a rich history of participating in the Southeast Asian Games, having first participated in 1959. The country has consistently performed well in the games, winning numerous medals in various sports. In the 2021 SEA Games, Malaysia finished fourth in the overall medal tally, winning a total of 111 medals, including 39 gold medals.

## Preparations

The Malaysian contingent has been preparing for the 2023 SEA Games since 2022. The Olympic Council of Malaysia (OCM) has been working closely with the National Sports Council (NSC) and the various national sports associations to identify and prepare athletes for the games. The athletes have been undergoing intensive training, both locally and abroad, to prepare themselves for the competition.

article:
Jackass Forever
================

Jackass Forever is a 2022 American action comedy film directed by Jeff Tremaine and the fourth main installment in the Jackass film series. The film stars Johnny Knoxville, Steve-O, Dave England, Wee Man, Chris Pontius, and Jason "Wee Man" Acuña, with guest appearances by various celebrities and athletes. The film marks the return of the Jackass crew to the big screen after a 12-year hiatus.

Synopsis
--------

The film follows the Jackass crew as they perform various stunts, pranks, and skits, often with hilarious and painful consequences. The movie features a mix of new and classic Jackass antics, including the return of fan-favorite characters and stunts. The film also explores the crew's relationships and personal struggles, offering a glimpse into their lives outside of the Jackass universe.

Cast
-----

The main cast of Jackass Forever includes:

* Johnny Knoxville as himself
* Steve-O as himself
* Dave England as himself
* Wee Man (Jason Acuña) as himself
* Chris Pontius as himself
* Preston Lacy as himself
* Ehren McGhehey as himself

## Guest appearances

The film features guest appearances by various celebrities and athletes, including:

* Machine Gun Kelly
* Shaquille O'Neal
* Eric Andre
* Tony Hawk
* Rob Dyrdek
* Travis Barker
* Post Malone

## Crew

The film was directed by Jeff Tremaine, who has directed all four main Jackass films. The screenplay was written by Tremaine, Knoxville, and Spike Jonze, with additional writing credits going to the rest of the Jackass crew.

Production
----------

### Development

Development on Jackass Forever began in 2018, with Knoxville and Tremaine meeting to discuss ideas for a new film. The pair wanted to create a film that would appeal to both old and new fans of the franchise, while also pushing the boundaries of what the crew could do on screen.

### Bam Margera's firing

In February 2021, it was announced that Bam Margera, a longtime member of the Jackass crew, would not be appearing in the film. Margera had been struggling with addiction and personal issues, and the decision was made to remove him from the production for his own well-being.

### Casting

The main cast of Jackass Forever was announced in May 2021, with the addition of new cast members including Jillian Bell and Rachel Wolfson. The film also features a number of celebrity cameos, including Shaquille O'Neal and Tony Hawk.

### Filming

Filming on Jackass Forever began in May 2021 and wrapped in August of the same year. The film was shot on location in Los Angeles and features a mix of stunts, pranks, and skits.

### Injuries

As with previous Jackass films, the crew suffered a number of injuries during filming. Steve-O was hospitalized after a particularly brutal stunt, while Knoxville suffered a number of broken bones throughout the shoot.

Release
-------

Jackass Forever was released in theaters on February 4, 2022, by Paramount Pictures. The film was originally scheduled for release in March 2021, but was delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

## Home media

The film was released on digital platforms on March 22, 2022, and on DVD and Blu-ray on April 19, 2022.

Reception
----------

### Box office

Jackass Forever grossed $57.7 million at the domestic box office and $90.1 million worldwide, making it the highest-grossing film in the Jackass franchise.

### Critical response

The film received generally positive reviews from critics, with many praising the crew's willingness to push the boundaries of what is acceptable on screen. The film holds a 85% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with an average rating of 6.5/10.

Jackass 4.5
------------

In May 2022, it was announced that a fifth Jackass film, titled Jackass 4.5, would be released on Netflix in 2023. The film will feature a mix of new and unseen footage from the production of Jackass Forever.

References
----------

External links

Assassination of John F. Kennedy

The assassination of John F. Kennedy, the 35th President of the United States, occurred on November 22, 1963, in Dallas, Texas. Kennedy was shot while riding in an open-top car in a motorcade through Dealey Plaza. He was struck by two bullets, one in the head and one in the neck, and was pronounced dead at Parkland Memorial Hospital. The assassination was a traumatic event in American history, leading to widespread shock, grief, and speculation about the circumstances surrounding the event.

John F. Kennedy was born on May 29, 1917, in Brookline, Massachusetts. He came from a prominent Irish-American family and was educated at Harvard University. Kennedy served in the U.S. Navy during World War II, commanding a patrol torpedo boat in the Pacific. After the war, he entered politics, serving in the U.S. House of Representatives and the U.S. Senate before being elected President in 1960. As President, Kennedy was known for his charismatic leadership style, his commitment to civil rights, and his aggressive stance against communism.

## Oswald

Lee Harvey Oswald was born on October 18, 1939, in New Orleans, Louisiana. He grew up in a troubled home, with his mother and father separating when he was young. Oswald dropped out of high school and joined the U.S. Marine Corps, where he was stationed in Japan. After his discharge, Oswald defected to the Soviet Union, where he lived for several years before returning to the United States. Oswald was a self-proclaimed Marxist and was known to have a troubled and unstable personality.

article:
2022 UK Championship

The 2022 UK Championship was a professional snooker tournament that took place from 12 to 20 November 2022 at the York Barbican in York, England. It was the 46th edition of the UK Championship and the third ranking tournament of the 2022–23 snooker season. The event was organized by the World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association (WPBSA) and sponsored by Cazoo.

# Format

The tournament featured 128 players, including 123 professional players from the World Snooker Tour and five amateur players who qualified through the Q School Order of Merit. The competition began with a qualifying round, followed by the main draw, which consisted of a series of knockout matches. The tournament was played as a single-elimination event, with all matches being best-of-11 frames.

## Prize fund

The total prize fund for the 2022 UK Championship was £850,000, with the winner receiving £170,000. The breakdown of the prize fund was as follows:

* Winner: £170,000
* Runner-up: £70,000
* Semi-finalists: £35,000
* Quarter-finalists: £20,000
* Last 16: £12,000
* Last 32: £8,000
* Last 64: £5,000
* Last 128: £2,500

# Summary

The 2022 UK Championship was won by Mark Allen, who defeated Ding Junhui 10–7 in the final. It was Allen's second UK Championship title, following his previous win in 2018. The tournament was marked by several upsets, including the defeat of defending champion Zhao Xintong in the second round.

## Qualifying rounds

The qualifying rounds took place from 5 to 10 November 2022 at the Ponds Forge International Sports Centre in Sheffield, England. The qualifying rounds featured 128 players, including 123 professional players and five amateur players. The top 16 players from the World Snooker Tour qualified automatically for the main draw, while the remaining 112 players competed in the qualifying rounds.

## First round

The first round of the main draw took place from 12 to 13 November 2022 and featured 64 players. The round saw several upsets, including the defeat of world number 14, Stuart Bingham, by amateur player Zak Surety.

## Second round

The second round took place from 14 to 15 November 2022 and featured 32 players. The round saw several high-profile defeats, including the loss of defending champion Zhao Xintong to Jack Lisowski.

## Quarter-finals

The quarter-finals took place on 18 November 2022 and featured eight players. The round saw several close matches, including the defeat of world number 3, Judd Trump, by Mark Allen.

## Semi-finals

The semi-finals took place on 19 November 2022 and featured four players. The round saw two close matches, with Mark Allen defeating Jack Lisowski 6–5 and Ding Junhui defeating Tom Ford 6–3.

## Final

The final took place on 20 November 2022 and featured Mark Allen and Ding Junhui. The match was closely contested, with Allen eventually winning 10–7.

The first five episodes of the season featured auditions in various cities across Greece, including Athens, Thessaloniki, and Crete. The contestants were selected based on their physical appearance, personality, and potential to become a successful model.

## Episodes 5–6: Bootcamp

In episodes 5 and 6, the selected contestants attended a bootcamp where they received training in modeling, makeup, and fashion. The contestants were also introduced to the show's judges and mentors.

## Episode 7: Wuthering Heights

In episode 7, the contestants participated in a photo shoot inspired by the novel "Wuthering Heights". The contestants wore Victorian-era clothing and posed in a dramatic landscape.

## Episode 8: Drive-Thru Diner

In episode 8, the contestants worked as waitresses at a drive-thru diner. They were challenged to take orders, serve food, and maintain a professional attitude while working in a fast-paced environment.

## Episode 9: Tennis

In episode 9, the contestants participated in a tennis game. They were challenged to wear high heels and play tennis while maintaining a glamorous appearance.

## Episode 10: Four Seasons Catwalk

In episode 10, the contestants walked the catwalk representing the four seasons. They wore clothing and accessories inspired by each season.

## Episode 11: Get The Job Done

In episode 11, the contestants were challenged to complete a series of tasks, including cooking, cleaning, and styling. They were evaluated on their ability to complete the tasks efficiently and effectively.

## Episode 12: Fashion In The City

In episode 12, the contestants participated in a fashion shoot inspired by city life. They wore modern clothing and posed in urban locations.

## Episode 13: The Makeover

In episode 13, the contestants received makeovers, including haircuts, makeup, and wardrobe changes. They were challenged to adapt to their new looks and personalities.

## Episode 14: Bikini Debate

In episode 14, the contestants participated in a debate about the history and cultural significance of the bikini. They wore bikinis and presented their arguments in a public forum.

## Episode 15: Back To The Future

In episode 15, the contestants participated in a time-travel themed photo shoot. They wore clothing and accessories from different eras and posed in futuristic settings.

## Episode 16: Alive & Kicking

In episode 16, the contestants participated in a fitness challenge. They were challenged to complete a series of physical tasks, including running, jumping, and lifting weights.

## Episode 17: Make Me Wet

In episode 17, the contestants participated in a water-themed photo shoot. They wore swimwear and posed in water-based settings.

## Episode 18: Sail Away

In episode 18, the contestants participated in a sailing challenge. They were challenged to navigate a sailboat and maintain a professional attitude while working in a team.

## Episode 19: Shine On

In episode 19, the contestants participated in a disco-themed photo shoot. They wore sparkling clothing and posed in a disco setting.

## Episode 20: Dirty Ride

In episode 20, the contestants participated in a car-themed photo shoot. They wore dirty and distressed clothing and posed with cars.

## Episode 21: Glam Wars

In episode 21, the contestants participated in a glam rock-themed photo shoot. They wore outrageous clothing and posed with musical instruments.

## Episode 22: Recycle Queen

In episode 22, the contestants participated in a recycling challenge. They were challenged to create clothing and accessories from recycled materials.

## Episode 23: Vamos Nammos

In episode 23, the contestants participated in a Greek-themed photo shoot. They wore traditional clothing and posed in a Greek setting.

## Episode 24: The After Party Effect

In episode 24, the contestants participated in an after-party themed photo shoot. They wore party clothing and posed in a nightclub setting.

## Episode 25: Transparency

In episode 25, the contestants participated in a see-through clothing photo shoot. They wore transparent clothing and posed in a minimalist setting.

## Episode 26: Rich Girl & Her Strange Pet

In episode 26, the contestants participated in a photo shoot with exotic animals. They wore luxurious clothing and posed with unusual pets.

## Episode 27: Driver's Seat

In episode 27, the contestants participated in a driving challenge. They were challenged to drive a car while maintaining a professional attitude and completing a series of tasks.

## Episode 28: Trip To Rome

In episode 28, the contestants traveled to Rome, Italy. They participated in a photo shoot inspired by Italian culture and history.

## Episode 29: Catwalk, Cabaret - Final Part 1

In episode 29, the contestants walked the catwalk in a cabaret-themed final challenge. They wore elaborate clothing and performed a choreographed routine.

## Episode 30: Video Clip - Final Part 2

In episode 30, the contestants participated in a music video-themed final challenge. They wore edgy clothing and performed in a music video setting.

article:
2022 United States House of Representatives elections in California

The 2022 United States House of Representatives elections in California were held on November 8, 2022, to elect the 52 U.S. Representatives from the state of California, one from each of the state's 52 congressional districts. The elections coincided with the 2022 midterm elections, where all 435 seats in the U.S. House of Representatives were contested, as well as other elections to the United States Senate, governorships, and local offices.

Overview

### Statewide

In the 2022 elections, California voters elected 52 members to the U.S. House of Representatives, with all 52 seats up for election. The elections were held using the new district boundaries drawn by the California Citizens Redistricting Commission following the 2020 United States Census.

### District

Each district is represented by one member of the U.S. House of Representatives. The candidates with the most votes in each district won the election and were elected to a two-year term.

District 1

### Candidates

#### Advanced to general

* Doug LaMalfa (Republican)
* Max Steiner (Democratic)

#### Eliminated in primary

* Rob Lydon (Democratic)
* David Peterson (Republican)

### Endorsements

* Doug LaMalfa: National Rifle Association, California Republican Party
* Max Steiner: California Democratic Party

### Predictions

* The Cook Political Report: Solid Republican
* Inside Elections: Solid Republican

article:
2023 World Baseball Classic

The 2023 World Baseball Classic is an international baseball tournament organized by the World Baseball Softball Confederation (WBSC) and sanctioned by the International Baseball Federation (IBAF). The fifth edition of the tournament, it features 20 national teams competing in a round-robin format, followed by a knockout stage. The event is considered one of the premier international competitions in baseball, showcasing the best players and teams from around the world.

# Teams

## Qualification

The qualification process for the 2023 World Baseball Classic involved a combination of automatic berths and a qualifying tournament. The top 12 teams from the 2017 World Baseball Classic, the top 4 teams from the WBSC Premier12 2019, and the top 4 teams from the WBSC World Rankings as of 2022 received automatic invitations. The remaining 4 spots were determined through a qualifying tournament, which featured 16 teams competing in two groups.

## Draw

The draw for the 2023 World Baseball Classic took place on July 7, 2022, in Miami, Florida. The 20 participating teams were divided into four pools of five teams each, with the teams seeded based on their WBSC World Rankings.

# Venues

The 2023 World Baseball Classic features six venues across four countries: Japan, Mexico, Taiwan, and the United States.

## Attendance

The tournament has seen significant attendance figures, with several games selling out. The largest attendance to date was recorded at the Tokyo Dome, with over 55,000 fans in attendance for a game between Japan and South Korea.

## Team base camps

Each participating team has its own base camp, where players and staff stay and train during the tournament. The base camps are located near the respective venues and provide teams with access to training facilities, medical services, and other amenities.

# Rosters

Each team is allowed to have a maximum of 28 players on its roster. The rosters feature a mix of established stars and young players, with many teams opting to include a balance of veterans and newcomers.

# Officiating

## Umpires

The 2023 World Baseball Classic features a team of experienced umpires from around the world. The umpires were selected based on their performance in previous international competitions and their expertise in specific areas of the game.

## Supervisors

A team of supervisors, led by the WBSC's Director of Umpiring, oversees the officiating during the tournament. The supervisors are responsible for evaluating the performance of the umpires and providing feedback and guidance.

# Prize money

The total prize money for the 2023 World Baseball Classic is $1 million, with the winning team receiving $500,000.

# Group stage

The group stage features 20 teams competing in four pools of five teams each. The top two teams from each pool advance to the knockout stage.

## Pool A

Pool A features Japan, South Korea, Australia, China, and the Czech Republic. Japan and South Korea are considered favorites to advance from the pool, with Australia and China also in contention.

## Pool B

Pool B features the United States, Mexico, Canada, Colombia, and the Netherlands. The United States and Mexico are expected to battle for the top spot in the pool, with Canada and the Netherlands also vying for a spot in the knockout stage.

## Pool C

Pool C features Taiwan, Venezuela, Italy, Puerto Rico, and the Dominican Republic. Taiwan and Venezuela are considered favorites to advance from the pool, with Italy and Puerto Rico also in contention.

## Pool D

Pool D features Israel, Great Britain, Spain, Germany, and France. Israel and Great Britain are expected to battle for the top spot in the pool, with Spain and Germany also vying for a spot in the knockout stage.

# Knockout stage

The knockout stage features the top two teams from each pool competing in a single-elimination format.

## Bracket

The bracket for the knockout stage features the winners of each pool facing the runners-up from the other pools. The semifinals feature the winners of the quarterfinals, with the winners advancing to the final.

## Quarterfinals

The quarterfinals feature the winners of each pool facing the runners-up from the other pools. The winners advance to the semifinals.

## Semifinals

The semifinals feature the winners of the quarterfinals. The winners advance to the final.

## Final

The final features the winners of the semifinals. The winner is crowned the champion of the 2023 World Baseball Classic.

# Awards

## Most Valuable Players

### Group stage

The most valuable player from each pool is awarded a trophy and a prize.

### Knockout stage

The most valuable player from the knockout stage is awarded a trophy and a prize.

## 2023 All-World Baseball Classic team

The 2023 All-World Baseball Classic team features the best players from the tournament, as selected by a panel of experts.

# Statistical leaders

The statistical leaders for the 2023 World Baseball Classic include leaders in batting average, home runs, RBIs, and ERA.

## Notes

* The 2023 World Baseball Classic features a number of notable records and milestones.
* The tournament has seen several close games and comebacks.

# Broadcasting

The 2023 World Baseball Classic is broadcast in over 200 countries and territories around the world.

## Television ratings

The tournament has seen significant television ratings, with several games drawing large audiences.

## Broadcasting rights

The broadcasting rights for the 2023 World Baseball Classic are held by a number of networks and streaming services around the world.

# Notes

* The 2023 World Baseball Classic is the fifth edition of the tournament.
* The tournament features a number of new and returning teams.

article:
John Green

John Green is an American author, YouTube personality, and educational content creator. He has written several bestselling novels for young adults, including "The Fault in Our Stars" and "Looking for Alaska," and has created numerous online educational series, such as "Crash Course" and "SciShow." Green's work often explores themes of mental health, existentialism, and the complexities of human relationships.

#Early life and education

John Michael Green was born on August 24, 1977, in Indianapolis, Indiana. He grew up in a family of modest means and was raised in a Christian household. Green's early life was marked by struggles with anxiety and depression, which he has spoken about publicly and incorporated into his writing.

Green attended Indiana University, where he studied English and graduated with a Bachelor's degree in 2000. During his college years, he worked as a student chaplain at a children's hospital and began to develop his writing skills.

#Career

##Early career and novels (2001–2006)

###Booklist magazine and Looking for Alaska

After college, Green moved to Chicago and began working as an associate editor for Booklist magazine. During this time, he started writing his first novel, "Looking for Alaska," which was published in 2005. The book tells the story of a teenager named Miles Halter, who enrolls in a boarding school and becomes infatuated with a mysterious girl named Alaska. The novel received critical acclaim and established Green as a rising star in the young adult literary scene.

###An Abundance of Katherines

In 2006, Green published his second novel, "An Abundance of Katherines," which explores the story of a teenager named Colin Singleton, who is struggling to come to terms with his recent breakup and his own sense of identity. The book received positive reviews and further solidified Green's reputation as a talented young author.

##Online and literary collaborations (2007–2011)

###Paper Towns and collaborative works

In 2008, Green published his third novel, "Paper Towns," which follows the story of a teenager named Quentin Jacobsen, who becomes obsessed with a mysterious girl named Margo Roth Spiegelman. The book was a commercial success and marked a turning point in Green's career.

During this period, Green also began to collaborate with other authors, including David Levithan and Maureen Johnson. He co-authored the novel "Will Grayson, Will Grayson" with Levithan, which was published in 2010.

###Online video beginnings

In 2007, Green and his brother, Hank, began creating online video content. They launched a YouTube channel called "VlogBrothers," where they posted video blogs about their lives, interests, and writing processes. The channel quickly gained a large following, and the brothers became known for their witty banter and insightful commentary on topics ranging from science to pop culture.

##Breakout success (2012–2016)

###The Fault in Our Stars and adaptations

In 2012, Green published his fourth novel, "The Fault in Our Stars," which tells the story of two teenagers with cancer who fall in love. The book was a massive commercial success, debuting at number one on the New York Times bestseller list and staying on the list for over a year. The book's success led to a film adaptation, which was released in 2014 and grossed over $304 million worldwide.

###Focus on educational content

In 2012, Green co-founded the online educational platform "Crash Course," which produces video courses on a range of subjects, including science, history, and literature. Green has hosted several Crash Course series, including "Crash Course World History" and "Crash Course Literature."

###Appearances

article:
Mahsa Amini Protests

The Mahsa Amini protests, also known as the Iran protests or the Iranian Revolution of 2022, refer to a series of anti-government protests and demonstrations that took place in Iran following the death of Mahsa Amini, a 22-year-old Kurdish Iranian woman, in police custody on September 16, 2022. Amini's death sparked widespread outrage and protests across Iran, with demonstrators calling for greater freedoms, an end to the country's strict dress code laws, and the overthrow of the Islamic Republic.

# Background

## Condition of women and the Islamic Republic

The Islamic Republic of Iran has been in power since the 1979 revolution, which overthrew the monarchy and established a theocratic government. Under the current regime, women's rights have been severely restricted, with laws enforcing strict dress codes, including the wearing of the hijab, or headscarf. Women are also subject to discriminatory laws and practices, including restrictions on their ability to travel, work, and access education.

## Protest movements under the Islamic Republic

Iran has a long history of protest movements, dating back to the 1990s, when students and intellectuals began to speak out against the regime's authoritarian policies. In 2009, mass protests broke out following the disputed presidential election, which saw the re-election of Mahmoud Ahmadinejad. The protests, known as the Green Movement, were brutally suppressed by the government, resulting in the deaths of dozens of protesters and the imprisonment of hundreds more.

## Mahsa Amini's arrest and death in custody

Mahsa Amini was arrested by Iran's morality police on September 13, 2022, for allegedly violating the country's strict dress code laws. She was taken to a police station in Tehran, where she was beaten and subjected to physical and psychological abuse. Amini fell into a coma and was taken to a hospital, where she died three days later. The government claimed that Amini had died of a heart attack, but her family and eyewitnesses disputed this account, saying that she had been severely beaten by the police.

# Protests

## Slogans and grievances

Protesters in Iran have been chanting slogans calling for greater freedoms, an end to the country's strict dress code laws, and the overthrow of the Islamic Republic. Demonstrators have also been demanding justice for Mahsa Amini and other victims of police brutality. The protests have been marked by a sense of outrage and anger, with many Iranians feeling that the government is out of touch with their needs and aspirations.

## Iranian public opinion

The protests have been widely supported by the Iranian public, with many people taking to social media to express their solidarity with the demonstrators. According to a recent survey, over 70% of Iranians support the protests, with many calling for greater freedoms and an end to the country's authoritarian policies.

## Protest techniques

Protesters in Iran have been using a range of tactics, including marching, chanting, and setting fire to government buildings and vehicles. Demonstrators have also been using social media to organize and coordinate their efforts, with many using encrypted messaging apps to communicate with each other.

## Civil boycotts

In addition to the protests, many Iranians have been participating in civil boycotts, refusing to buy goods and services from companies that support the government. The boycotts have been targeting companies that have been accused of collaborating with the regime, including telecommunications companies and banks.

## Media Western coverage

The protests in Iran have received widespread coverage in the Western media, with many outlets reporting on the bravery and determination of the protesters. However, some critics have accused the Western media of being biased in their coverage, with some outlets focusing too much on the protests and not enough on the government's response.

# Casualties, government response

## Casualties

According to human rights groups, over 200 protesters have been killed in the crackdown, with many more injured. The government has also been accused of using excessive force, including tear gas, batons, and live ammunition.

### Government casualties

The government has reported that several security forces have been killed in the clashes, with some reports suggesting that as many as 20 police officers have been killed.

## Arrests and death sentences

Over 10,000 protesters have been arrested in the crackdown, with many facing charges of rioting, vandalism, and other crimes. Some protesters have also been sentenced to death, with several reports suggesting that the government is planning to execute dozens of protesters in the coming weeks.

### Executions

In December 2022, the Iranian government executed two protesters, Mohammad Mehdi Karami and Seyyed Mohammad Hosseini, who had been convicted of killing a security force member during the protests. The executions were widely condemned by human rights groups and Western governments.

## Suspected food poisoning

In recent weeks, there have been reports of suspected food poisoning among university students and schoolgirls in Iran. The incidents have sparked widespread concern, with many fearing that the government is using poison to target protesters.

### University students

Several university students have reported falling ill after eating food in their dormitories, with some reports suggesting that the food was poisoned.

### Schoolgirls

There have also been reports of schoolgirls falling ill after eating food in their schools, with some reports suggesting that the food was poisoned.

## Statements by officials

Government officials have been making statements in recent weeks, with some calling for greater calm and others warning protesters of the consequences of their actions.

## Government strategy and tactics

The government has been using a range of strategies and tactics to suppress the protests, including the use of force, arrests, and propaganda. The government has also been trying to discredit the protesters, accusing them of being agents of foreign powers.

## Communications blackouts

The government has been imposing communications blackouts in areas where the protests are taking place, making it difficult for protesters to communicate with each other.

## Response by regime supporters

Regime supporters have been responding to the protests, with some calling for greater action against the protesters. There have also been reports of regime supporters attacking protesters, with some incidents resulting in serious injuries.

## Government campaign for public opinion

The government has been launching a campaign to win public opinion, with some officials making statements calling for greater calm and others warning protesters of the consequences of their actions.

# Aftermath

## Lack of head covering

In the aftermath of the protests, many Iranian women have been refusing to wear the hijab, or headscarf, in public. The move has been seen as a symbol of resistance against the government's strict dress code laws.

### Crackdown

The government has been cracking down on women who refuse to wear the hijab, with some reports suggesting that women are being arrested and fined for not wearing the headscarf.

### Surveillance of protesters and dissidents

The government has been increasing surveillance of protesters and dissidents, with some reports suggesting that the government is using social media to monitor the activities of activists.

# Analysis

The protests in Iran have been seen as a significant challenge to the government's authority, with many analysts suggesting that the regime is facing a major crisis. The protests have also been seen as a symbol of the ongoing struggle for human rights and democracy in Iran.

# International reactions

## International organizations

International organizations, including the United Nations and the European Union, have been condemning the government's response to the protests, with some calling for greater restraint and others calling for sanctions.

## Diplomatic ties

The protests have also been affecting diplomatic ties between Iran and other countries, with some countries recalling their ambassadors and others imposing sanctions.

## Human rights advocates

Human rights advocates have been calling for greater action to support the protesters, with some calling for sanctions and others calling for diplomatic pressure.

## Sanctions

The United States and other countries have been imposing sanctions on Iran in response to the government's human rights record, with some reports suggesting that the sanctions are having a significant impact on the country's economy.

# In popular culture

## Music

The protests have been inspiring artists and musicians, with some releasing songs and music videos in support of the protesters.

## Sports

The protests have also been affecting sports, with some Iranian athletes refusing to compete in international competitions in solidarity with the protesters.

### 2022 FIFA World Cup

The protests have also been affecting the 2022 FIFA World Cup, with some Iranian players refusing to sing the national anthem in solidarity with the protesters.

### Commercialism

The protests have also been affecting commercialism, with some companies pulling their advertisements from Iranian media outlets in response to the government's human rights record.

Celebrity Big Brother 3 (American season)

Celebrity Big Brother 3 is the third season of the American reality television series Celebrity Big Brother. The season premiered on February 2, 2022, and concluded on February 23, 2022. # Production

## Production design

The season's production design was led by Scott Storey, who designed the custom-built house and its interior. The house featured a tropical theme, with a focus on comfort and luxury. The contestants had access to a range of amenities, including a pool, a hot tub, and a gym.

article:
Uncharted (film)
================

Uncharted is a 2022 American action-adventure film directed by Ruben Fleischer and written by Rafe Lee Judkins, Art Marcum, and Matt Holloway. The film is based on the popular video game series of the same name developed by Naughty Dog. The movie follows the story of Nathan Drake, a young treasure hunter, and his mentor Victor Sullivan as they embark on a perilous journey to find a long-lost treasure.

Plot
-----

The film opens with a young Nathan Drake (Tom Holland) working as a bartender in New York City. Nathan is approached by Victor Sullivan (Mark Wahlberg), a seasoned treasure hunter, who claims to have information about Nathan's long-lost brother Sam. Sullivan convinces Nathan to join him on a treasure hunt to find the lost riches of Ferdinand Magellan, a famous explorer.

The duo soon finds themselves in a high-stakes adventure, racing against wealthy collector Moncada (Antonio Banderas) and his ruthless mercenaries. Along the way, Nathan and Sullivan must navigate treacherous jungle terrain, avoid deadly traps, and fight off rival treasure hunters.

As they get closer to their goal, Nathan begins to unravel the mystery surrounding his brother's disappearance and the true nature of Sullivan's intentions. The film's climax features an action-packed sequence as Nathan and Sullivan face off against Moncada and his team in a desperate bid to claim the treasure.

Cast
----

* Tom Holland as Nathan Drake
* Mark Wahlberg as Victor Sullivan

### Development

The film adaptation of Uncharted has been in development since 2008, with various directors and writers attached to the project over the years. In 2016, Sony Pictures announced that Shawn Levy would direct the film, with Tom Holland set to star as Nathan Drake. However, Levy dropped out of the project in 2018, and Ruben Fleischer was brought on board to direct.

### Pre-production

Pre-production on the film began in 2019, with Fleischer working closely with the writers to develop the script. The film's budget was set at around $120 million, and the cast was finalized with the addition of Mark Wahlberg, Antonio Banderas, and Sophia Ali.

### Filming

Principal photography began in March 2020, with filming taking place in various locations around the world, including Spain, Italy, and the Dominican Republic. However, production was halted in March 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Filming resumed in July 2020, with the cast and crew adhering to strict health and safety protocols.

### Theatrical

Uncharted was released in theaters on February 18, 2022, in the United States. The film received a wide release, with showings in over 4,000 theaters across the country.

The film was banned in the Philippines and Vietnam due to concerns over its depiction of historical figures and cultural artifacts. In the Philippines, the film was criticized for its portrayal of Ferdinand Magellan, a Spanish explorer who arrived in the country in the 16th century. The film received mixed reviews from critics, with some praising its action-packed sequences and performances, while others criticized its storyline and pacing. On Rotten Tomatoes, the film holds a 68% approval rating, based on 242 reviews, with an average rating of 6.1/10.

article:
Women's Cinema
================

Women's cinema refers to the cinema created by women, either in front of or behind the camera, and often addressing women's issues, experiences, and perspectives. The history of women's cinema is as old as the history of cinema itself, with women playing a significant role in the development of the medium. This article explores the history of women's cinema, its impact on society, and the contributions of women filmmakers from around the world.

Famous Women in Film History
-----------------------------

### Silent Films

During the silent era, women played a crucial role in the development of cinema. Actresses like Mary Pickford, Lillian Gish, and Clara Bow were among the most popular stars of the time. Women like Alice Guy-Blaché and Lois Weber were also pioneers behind the camera, directing and producing their own films.

### Classical Hollywood

In the classical Hollywood era, women like Bette Davis, Katharine Hepburn, and Joan Crawford became iconic stars. Women like Dorothy Arzner and Ida Lupino also made a name for themselves as directors and producers. Arzner was the first woman to direct a sound film, and Lupino was one of the first women to produce and direct her own films.

### Experimental and Avant-Garde Cinema

Women like Maya Deren and Shirley Clarke were pioneers of experimental and avant-garde cinema. Deren's films like "Meshes of the Afternoon" (1943) and "Ritual in Transfigured Time" (1946) are considered classics of the genre. Clarke's films like "The Connection" (1961) and "Portrait of Jason" (1967) explored themes of identity and social justice.

Impact on Society
-----------------

### Impact of Second-Wave Feminism

The second-wave feminist movement of the 1960s and 1970s had a significant impact on women's cinema. Films like "A Woman Under the Influence" (1974) and "Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore" (1974) addressed issues of women's liberation and equality. Women like Chantal Akerman and Agnès Varda became prominent figures in the feminist film movement.

### Representing Sexuality

Women's cinema has also played a significant role in representing women's sexuality. Films like "The Piano" (1993) and "Blue Is the Warmest Colour" (2013) explored themes of female desire and pleasure. Women like Jane Campion and Abdellatif Kechiche won critical acclaim for their portrayal of women's sexuality on screen.

### Fear of Entering Cinematography

Despite the progress made by women in cinema, many women still fear entering the industry. The lack of representation and opportunities for women behind the camera is a major concern. Women like Ava DuVernay and Patty Jenkins have spoken out about the challenges they faced in their careers.

### Statistics

According to a 2020 report, women made up only 15% of directors and 21% of writers in the film industry. The report also found that women were underrepresented in key roles like cinematography and editing.

### Documentaries

Documentaries like "The Celluloid Closet" (1995) and "This Changes Everything" (2018) have explored the representation of women in cinema. The films feature interviews with women like Barbra Streisand and Meryl Streep, who share their experiences of working in the industry.

#### Female Filmmakers as Feminists

Many female filmmakers have identified as feminists and have used their films to address issues of social justice. Women like Sofia Coppola and Lynne Ramsay have spoken about the importance of feminism in their work.

### Celluloid Ceiling

The term "celluloid ceiling" refers to the barriers that women face in the film industry. Women like Sherry Lansing and Amy Pascal have spoken out about the challenges they faced in their careers. The term has been used to describe the lack of representation and opportunities for women behind the camera.

The 2022 European Aquatics Championships was the 35th edition of the European Aquatics Championships, a European championship event organized by LEN (Ligue Européenne de Natation), which took place in Rome, Italy from August 11 to August 21, 2022. article:
HIT: The Second Case
=====================

HIT: The Second Case is a 2022 Indian Telugu-language crime thriller film written and directed by Sailesh Kolanu. The film is a sequel to the 2020 film HIT: The First Case and stars Adivi Sesh and Meenakshi Chaudhary in the lead roles. The movie follows the story of a police officer who is tasked with solving a mystery surrounding a missing woman.

Plot
-----

The film begins with a young woman named Sanjana, who goes missing in the city of Visakhapatnam. Her father, a retired police officer, approaches the HIT (Homicide Intervention Team) department, led by KD (Adivi Sesh), to help find his daughter. KD, who has a reputation for being one of the best officers in the department, takes on the case and starts investigating.

As KD delves deeper into the case, he discovers that Sanjana's disappearance is linked to a larger conspiracy involving a powerful businessman and a corrupt police officer. KD must navigate through the complex web of relationships and alliances to uncover the truth behind Sanjana's disappearance.

Throughout the investigation, KD is aided by his team, including his colleague and friend, Rohan. Together, they follow a trail of clues and piece together the events leading up to Sanjana's disappearance. As the investigation unfolds, KD's own dark past begins to surface, threatening to jeopardize the case and his relationships with those around him.

Cast
-----

* Adivi Sesh as KD
* Meenakshi Chaudhary as Aarya
* Rao Ramesh as Ramulu
* Srikanth Iyengar as DGP
* Komalee Prasad as Rohan
* Praveen Sattaru as Police Commissioner

Production
------------

HIT: The Second Case began production in 2021, with Sailesh Kolanu returning as the director and writer. The film was produced by Prashanti Tipirneni under the banner of Wall Poster Cinema. The movie was shot on location in Visakhapatnam and Hyderabad, with cinematography handled by S. Manikandan.

The film's script was reportedly written in just 15 days, with Kolanu drawing inspiration from real-life crimes and his own experiences as a writer. Adivi Sesh, who also starred in the first HIT film, was the first choice to play the lead role of KD. Meenakshi Chaudhary was cast as the female lead after a rigorous auditioning process.

Music
------

The music for HIT: The Second Case was composed by John Stewart Eduri, with lyrics written by Krishna Kanth. The film's soundtrack features four songs, including the hit single "Urike Urike". The music was well-received by critics and audiences alike, with many praising the film's background score and sound design.

Release
--------

HIT: The Second Case was released on December 2, 2022, in theaters across India. The film received a U/A certificate from the Central Board of Film Certification (CBFC) and was released in Telugu, with dubbed versions in Tamil, Hindi, and Malayalam.

The film's trailer was released on November 15, 2022, and generated significant buzz on social media. The film's promotions were handled by Wall Poster Cinema, with Adivi Sesh and Meenakshi Chaudhary attending various events and interviews to promote the movie.

Reception
----------

HIT: The Second Case received generally positive reviews from critics, with many praising the film's engaging storyline, strong performances, and slick direction. The film's action sequences and music were also widely praised.

The film was a commercial success, grossing over ₹50 crore at the box office in its opening weekend. The film's success was attributed to its strong word-of-mouth and positive reviews, with many audiences praising the film's twists and turns.

article:
2022 Brazilian General Election

The 2022 Brazilian general election was held on October 2, 2022, to elect the president, vice president, and members of the National Congress. The election was marked by a highly polarized campaign, with incumbent president Jair Bolsonaro seeking re-election against former president Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.

# Background

Brazil's presidential system is characterized by a strong executive and a bicameral legislature. The president serves a four-year term and is limited to two consecutive terms. The National Congress consists of the Chamber of Deputies and the Federal Senate, with members serving four-year and eight-year terms, respectively. The election was held in the context of a severe economic crisis, high levels of unemployment, and a devastating COVID-19 pandemic.

# Electoral System

Brazil's electoral system is based on proportional representation, with voters casting ballots for candidates for the Chamber of Deputies and Federal Senate. The president and vice president are elected through a majority vote, with a runoff held if no candidate receives more than 50% of the vote in the first round.

## Voters

Brazilian citizens aged 18 to 70 are required to vote, while those aged 16 to 17 and over 70 are eligible to vote but not required to do so. The country has a large and diverse electorate, with over 156 million registered voters.

## Candidates and Political Parties

A total of 12 candidates ran for president, representing various political parties. The main candidates were incumbent president Jair Bolsonaro (Liberal Party) and former president Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva (Workers' Party).

## Procedure

The election was held in two rounds, with the first round taking place on October 2, 2022, and the runoff held on October 30, 2022. Voting was compulsory for all eligible citizens, and voters were required to present identification and proof of registration at polling stations.

# Presidential Candidates

## Candidates in Runoff

The two candidates who advanced to the runoff were incumbent president Jair Bolsonaro and former president Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.

## Candidates Not Advanced to Runoff

## Withdrawn or Declined to be Candidates

Several candidates withdrew or declined to run for president, including:

* Sergio Moro (Podemos)
* João Doria (Brazilian Social Democracy Party)

article:
Jude Bellingham

Jude Victor William Bellingham is an English professional footballer who plays as a midfielder for La Liga club Real Madrid and the England national team. He is widely regarded as one of the most promising young players in the world.

# Early life and education

Jude Bellingham was born on June 29, 2003, in Stourbridge, West Midlands, England. He began playing football at a young age and joined the Birmingham City academy at the age of eight. Bellingham attended Priory School in Birmingham, where he excelled academically and on the sports field. He was an avid fan of Birmingham City and regularly attended matches at St Andrew's Stadium.

# Club career

## Birmingham City

Bellingham progressed through the Birmingham City youth ranks, making his debut for the club's under-18 team at the age of 14. He quickly established himself as a key player, scoring crucial goals and providing assists. In 2019, Bellingham signed his first professional contract with Birmingham City, committing himself to the club until 2023.

Bellingham made his first-team debut for Birmingham City on August 6, 2019, in a Championship match against Portsmouth. He became the youngest player to start a match for the club at the age of 16 years and 38 days, breaking a record held by Trevor Francis. Bellingham's impressive performances for Birmingham City caught the attention of several top-tier clubs, including Borussia Dortmund, who eventually signed him in July 2020.

## Borussia Dortmund

### 2020–2021: Transfer and record-breaking achievements

Bellingham joined Borussia Dortmund on July 23, 2020, for a reported transfer fee of €22 million. He became the most expensive 17-year-old player in history, breaking a record held by Mateo Kovačić. Bellingham made his debut for Borussia Dortmund on September 14, 2020, in a DFB-Pokal match against MSV Duisburg. He scored his first goal for the club on October 3, 2020, in a Bundesliga match against Hoffenheim.

Bellingham's impressive performances for Borussia Dortmund earned him numerous accolades, including the Bundesliga Rookie of the Month award for September 2020. He became the youngest player to score a goal in the Champions League for Borussia Dortmund, breaking a record held by Nuri Şahin.

### 2021–2023: Bundesliga Player of the Season and league runner-up

Bellingham's second season at Borussia Dortmund was marked by significant improvement, as he established himself as a key player in the team. He scored crucial goals and provided assists, helping Borussia Dortmund finish as runners-up in the Bundesliga. Bellingham's performances earned him the Bundesliga Player of the Season award, becoming the youngest player to receive the honor.

## Real Madrid

### 2023–24: Debut season and goalscoring records

Bellingham joined Real Madrid on June 14, 2023, for a reported transfer fee of €100 million. He became one of the most expensive signings in Real Madrid's history, breaking a record held by Gareth Bale. Bellingham made his debut for Real Madrid on August 12, 2023, in a La Liga match against Celta Vigo. He scored his first goal for the club on August 19, 2023, in a La Liga match against Almería.

Bellingham's impressive performances for Real Madrid earned him numerous accolades, including the La Liga Player of the Month award for August 2023. He became the youngest player to score a goal in El Clásico, breaking a record held by Lionel Messi.

### 2024–25: Second season and European Super Cup

Bellingham's second season at Real Madrid was marked by significant success, as the club won the European Super Cup. He played a crucial role in the final, providing an assist and helping Real Madrid win the trophy. Bellingham's performances earned him numerous accolades, including the UEFA Super Cup Man of the Match award.

# International career

## Youth career

Bellingham represented England at various youth levels, including the under-15, under-16, and under-17 teams. He made his debut for the England under-15 team on February 5, 2018, in a match against Turkey. Bellingham scored his first goal for the England under-15 team on March 27, 2018, in a match against Belgium.

## Senior career

Bellingham made his debut for the England senior team on November 12, 2020, in a friendly match against the Republic of Ireland. He became the third-youngest player to debut for England, behind only Theo Walcott and Jack Wilshere. Bellingham scored his first goal for the England senior team on June 6, 2021, in a friendly match against Romania.

## UEFA Euro 2024

Bellingham was selected for the England squad for the UEFA Euro 2024. He played a crucial role in the tournament, scoring crucial goals and providing assists. Bellingham's performances earned him numerous accolades, including the UEFA Euro 2024 Young Player of the Tournament award.

# Style of play

Bellingham is a versatile midfielder who can play in various positions, including central midfield, attacking midfield, and wide midfield. He is known for his exceptional dribbling skills, vision, and passing range. Bellingham is also an prolific goal-scorer, with a high conversion rate from midfield.

# Outside football

Bellingham is an avid fan of music and often attends concerts in his free time. He is also a fan of video games and often streams his gameplay on social media platforms.

article:
Collapse of Silicon Valley Bank

The Collapse of Silicon Valley Bank was a significant financial event that occurred in 2023, resulting in the failure of one of the largest banks in the United States. Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) was a commercial bank that catered primarily to the tech industry, providing financial services to startups, venture capital firms, and other technology companies. The bank's collapse sent shockwaves through the financial system, raising concerns about the stability of the banking sector and the potential impact on the broader economy.

#Background

Silicon Valley Bank was founded in 1983 and was headquartered in Santa Clara, California. The bank grew rapidly over the years, becoming one of the largest banks in the United States, with over $200 billion in assets. SVB was known for its expertise in serving the tech industry, providing a range of financial services, including lending, deposit accounts, and investment banking. The bank's customer base included many prominent tech companies, such as Apple, Google, and Facebook, as well as numerous startups and venture capital firms.

In the years leading up to its collapse, SVB had experienced rapid growth, fueled by the expansion of the tech industry. However, this growth also led to increased competition and pressure to maintain profitability. SVB had invested heavily in long-term bonds, which had declined in value due to rising interest rates. Additionally, the bank had a high concentration of deposits from tech companies, which were subject to withdrawal at short notice.

#Collapse

The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank occurred on March 10, 2023, when the bank's parent company, SVB Financial Group, announced that it was seeking to raise additional capital to shore up its finances. However, the bank's efforts to raise capital were unsuccessful, and on March 10, the California Department of Financial Protection and Innovation (DFPI) took possession of SVB, placing it into receivership.

##Losses

The collapse of SVB resulted in significant losses for the bank's customers and shareholders. Many tech companies had deposited large sums of money with SVB, which were now at risk of being lost. Additionally, the bank's shareholders saw the value of their investments plummet, with the bank's stock price falling by over 80% in the days leading up to its collapse.

##Instability

The collapse of SVB also raised concerns about the stability of the financial system. The bank's failure was the largest since the 2008 financial crisis, and it raised fears about the potential for a broader banking crisis. Many experts warned that the collapse of SVB could have a ripple effect, leading to a loss of confidence in the banking system and potentially triggering a wider financial crisis.

##Receivership

Following the collapse of SVB, the FDIC was appointed as the receiver to manage the bank's assets and liabilities. The FDIC's primary goal was to minimize disruption to the bank's customers and to maximize the recovery of assets. The FDIC worked to sell off the bank's assets, including its loan portfolio and securities holdings, to other banks and investors.

##Acquisition

On March 26, 2023, the FDIC announced that it had sold SVB's assets to First Citizens Bank, a North Carolina-based bank. The sale included SVB's loan portfolio, securities holdings, and deposits. The acquisition was seen as a positive development, as it would help to stabilize the financial system and provide continuity for SVB's customers.

#Effects

The collapse of SVB had significant effects on the bank's customers, shareholders, and the broader financial system.

##Customers

Many of SVB's customers were tech companies, which were heavily reliant on the bank for their financial needs. The collapse of SVB left these companies facing significant uncertainty, as they struggled to access their funds and conduct their day-to-day business. However, the sale of SVB's assets to First Citizens Bank helped to alleviate some of these concerns, as it provided continuity for the bank's customers.

##Shareholders

The collapse of SVB resulted in significant losses for the bank's shareholders. The bank's stock price plummeted in the days leading up to its collapse, wiping out billions of dollars in shareholder value. Many shareholders were left facing significant financial losses, as they struggled to come to terms with the bank's failure.

##Financial system

The collapse of SVB raised concerns about the stability of the financial system. The bank's failure was the largest since the 2008 financial crisis, and it raised fears about the potential for a broader banking crisis. However, the sale of SVB's assets to First Citizens Bank helped to alleviate some of these concerns, as it provided continuity for the bank's customers and helped to stabilize the financial system.

##Legal actions

In the aftermath of the collapse, several lawsuits were filed against SVB and its executives, alleging that they had engaged in reckless and negligent behavior. The lawsuits claimed that the bank's executives had failed to properly manage the bank's risk and had misled investors about the bank's financial condition.

#Reactions

The collapse of SVB sparked a range of reactions, from official responses to debates about government intervention and the causes of the bank's failure.

##Official responses

The collapse of SVB prompted a swift response from regulators and government officials. The FDIC was appointed as the receiver to manage the bank's assets and liabilities, and the Treasury Department and Federal Reserve issued statements reassuring the public about the stability of the financial system.

##Debate over government intervention

The collapse of SVB also sparked a debate about the role of government intervention in the banking system. Some argued that the government should have done more to prevent the bank's failure, while others argued that the government's actions had contributed to the bank's collapse.

##Debate about causes

The collapse of SVB also sparked a debate about the causes of the bank's failure. Some argued that the bank's collapse was the result of poor management and excessive risk-taking, while others argued that the bank's failure was the result of broader economic and regulatory factors.

The Masked Singer (American TV series) season 8

The eighth season of the American television series The Masked Singer premiered on September 21, 2022, on Fox. The season features a new cast of celebrity contestants competing against each other in a singing competition, with their identities hidden behind elaborate costumes and masks.

# Panelists and host

The panelists for season 8 include Ken Jeong, Jenny McCarthy Wahlberg, Nicole Scherzinger, and Robin Thicke. The show is hosted by Nick Cannon.

# Production

The eighth season of The Masked Singer was produced by Fox Alternative Entertainment and Smart Dog Media. The show was filmed in front of a live studio audience at the CBS Television City in Los Angeles, California.

# Contestants

The contestants for season 8 include:

* Avocado (Chris Kirkpatrick)
* Bride (Kat Graham)
* Harp (Amber Riley)
* Knight (William Shatner)
* Maize (Donny Osmond)
* Mermaid (Heather Graham)
* Pi-Rat (Jeffrey Osborne)
* Queen Cobra (Michelle Williams)
* Robo-Giraffe (Kristin Chenoweth)
* Snail (Tori Spelling)
* Venus Flytrap (George Clinton)

# Episodes

## Week 1 (September 21)

The season premiere featured the first group of contestants performing, including Avocado, Bride, Harp, and Knight. The episode also featured a special guest appearance by season 7 winner, Firefly.

## Week 2 (September 28) - "Vegas Night"

The second episode featured the remaining contestants performing, including Maize, Mermaid, Pi-Rat, and Queen Cobra. The episode was themed around Las Vegas, with the contestants performing songs that were popular in the city.

## Week 3 (October 5) - "TV Theme Night"

The third episode featured the contestants performing TV theme songs, including the themes from "The Brady Bunch", "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air", and "The Muppet Show".

## Week 4 (October 19) - "Andrew Lloyd Webber Night"

The fourth episode featured the contestants performing songs from the musicals of Andrew Lloyd Webber, including "The Phantom of the Opera" and "Cats".

## Week 5 (October 26) - "Muppets Night"

The fifth episode featured the contestants performing songs from The Muppet Show, including "Mah Na Mah Na" and "The Rainbow Connection".

## Week 6 (November 6 and 9) - "90s Night" and "Hall of Fame Night"

The sixth episode was a special two-part episode, with the first part featuring the contestants performing songs from the 1990s, and the second part featuring the contestants performing songs that have been inducted into the Grammy Hall of Fame.

## Week 7 (November 16) - "Comedy Roast Night"

The seventh episode featured the contestants performing in a comedy roast format, with each contestant taking turns performing jokes and songs that poked fun at themselves and the other contestants.

## Week 8 (November 23 and 24) - "Fright Night" and "Battle of the Semi Finals"

The eighth episode was a special two-part episode, with the first part featuring the contestants performing in a special "Fright Night" themed episode, and the second part featuring the contestants competing in the semi-finals.

## Week 9 (November 30) - "Two Hour Epic Finale"

The season finale featured the last three contestants competing for the title of The Masked Singer, with a special two-hour episode that included a performance by season 7 runner-up, Bull.

# Ratings

The eighth season of The Masked Singer averaged a 1.2 rating in the 18-49 demographic and 4.3 million viewers per episode.

# Notes

The eighth season of The Masked Singer was the first season to feature a new format, with the contestants competing in a special "Battle Royale" format in the semi-finals. The season also featured a number of special guest appearances, including a performance by the winner of season 7, Firefly.
